title: hugs clean air holidays gadgets trends 2020
story: The -year-old predicted the clean eating craze, the rise of the snowflake generation and metrosexual men and she was one of the first to warn of the  financial crash.Today we hear what New Yorker Marian – whose Annual Trends report is a bible for companies wanting to know the next big thing – is predicting for , which she believes will be the Year of the Hug.It has never been easier to reach out to friends and colleagues anywhere in the world.But the more digitally connected we all become, the more we risk becoming disconnected emotionally and physically.We each live in our own inidualised, personally curated bubble — and we are feeling the impact.At our core, humans are social animals. We need contact — and not just emotional — but physical.There’s even a psychological term for it, skin hunger.People are responding to this tech-driven disconnect by seeking out physical contact in any way they can.The most obvious example is the rise of hugging.There’s a lot more hugging as a greeting between men than there used to be, even between sporting opponents.And what on earth happened to the stand-offish Brits  Great British Bake Off contestants spend nearly as much time holding hands and wrapping their arms around each other as they do baking.We have become so hungry for touch that we don’t even need a human partner.The odds are that someone you know will have received a weighted blanket for Christmas.It is essentially a duvet cover filled with plastic or glass pellets or beads.Manufacturers say the even pressure they exert on your body promotes the release of well-being chemical serotonin and sleep hormone melatonin, while reducing stress-related hormone cortisol.In plain language we’re talking about feeling the comfort and security of being cradled, evenit’s by a blanket rather than in the arms of a loved one.For those who want to take the experience of being hugged to a whole new level, Otonamaki, the Japanese practice of adult swaddling, will become popular in .After getting into a foetal position, the client is bound tightly in sheets, then gently rocked for  minutes.I ran across a tweet not long ago that read: “My phone just said, ‘Welcome home’, and I instinctively replied, ‘I love you’. Then I realised I meant it.”We may be interacting with our fellow humans less often, but we’re more than making up for it with digital interactions, even to the point of developing feelings for these devices.As our devices get smarter and master the intricacies of natural language processing, we will increasingly see them as confidants, friends and even romantic partners.Already people are interacting with chatbots instead of flesh-and-blood therapists.And we’re seeing all sorts of digital apps promising to improve our mental health, from Moodfit and MoodMission to Happy.As developers figure out how to make our smart devices ever more personable, it doesn’t take a soothsayer to recognise that a global population increasingly suffering from loneliness and disconnectedness will find solutions of a sort in these gadgets.The desire for clean air in cities will not only lead to pricier houses on less polluted streets but tourists will give up city breaks for holidays in the country, where the air is good.As living in places with clean air becomes a luxury with a high price tag, expect new takes on face masks to become a must-have item for people in cities and a race towards rural living.Expect an explosion of products, from vegan leather to plant-based burgers and articial wood.If you buy a vegan burger and cook it at home, you have consumed a burger made with eight times less water and CO than a conventional beef burger.These sorts of products may be described as “fake” but the feelings people get of having made an ethically better choice are very real.Uncertainty begets fear, so look out for a rise in preppers — survivalists preparing for Armageddon.In the US, prepping is mainstream enough for Costco to sell a £, one-year stockpile of survival food for four.Survivalists are at the extreme end of the bunker trend.More mainstream are the millions who aren’t worried enough to go all-out prepper but still view the outside world as a threat.Driven by concerns about personal security and terrorism, CCTV covering public and commercial spaces is becoming a global norm.London is sixth in the world for TV surveillance, the only non-Chinese city in the top eight.And sales of home video surveillance on smartphones, courtesy of Google Nest, Ring and Wyze Cam, are booming.The global market is expected to rise from £billion to £billion by .Expect the self-tracking trend to run and run.For more and more people, there’s something irresistible about gadgets that put statistics to common everyday activities.For things that can’t yet be tracked automatically, they can input data manually — MyMoodTracker for emotions, MyNetDiary for nutrition and PoopLog for toilet visits.Google announced it intended to buy Fitbit for nearly £billion, prompting some to say they will ditch their device out of concern that Google will sell their health data to insurance companies.But rather than wait to buy third-party data, insurance companies are already getting into the game.: Single, professional women will become the new free-spending yuppies.: Publishes a study of the soft modern male, who she described as “metrosexual man”.: Predicts “sleep is the new sex” and “clean eating”. Forecasts the sub-prime crisis that led to the  financial crash.: Identies a new “snowflake” mindset where “everybody wants to save the Earth but no one wants to help Mum with the dishes”.: Identies Daddy bloggers as more fathers bring up kids.: Forecasts the rise of “truthiness” – where facts seem to matter little.: Predicts rise of gender-neutral society. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cats seized micro chipped plans
story: The Government is consulting on making it compulsory for all Brits to get their felines chipped.It is already illegal for dog owners to not microchip their pets, and those who flout the law can be prosecuted and handed £ fines.One proposal being considered is handing councils the power to seize the cats and get them microchipped.The pets would then be given back to their owners who would be billed for the ID tag, typically around £.But the owner could face a finethey refused to pay the bill.The consultation on the proposed shake-up closes on January .Zac Goldsmith, Animal Welfare Minister, said: “Microchips are often the only hope of reuniting lost pets with their owners so it truly is the best New Year’s resolution you could make to protect your furry friend in .“I urge cat owners to microchip their cat and for dog-owners to make sure the details on the chip are up to date.”Jacqui Cuff, from the charity Cats Protection, said: “It is so important that cat owners microchip their pet cats as it is a safe and permanent form of identication.“Cats love to explore, and are also great escape artists, so microchipping is important for cats, even those that live indoors.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn fans sign petition to get him to stay labour leader
story: An online petition shared by Mr Corbyns own brother Piers urging him to reverse his decision to resign has gathered more than , signatures already. Piers Corbyn wrote on Twitter today: Sign this very very very important petition to support #Corbynshouldstay #KeepCorbyn #Corbynmuststand.This is the way forward streets ahead of all .Do it now and pass it on.The petitions authors wrote: Lets stand up to the bullying establishment and refuse to play their games.If Jeremy Corbyn wants to stay on as leader, we would support him %.It blames the partys Brexit policy and Jeremy Corbyns lack of popularity with voters as the reasons for losing last months snap election.But it points the finger at the establishment for smearing the Labour boss, and pledges its full support to him as the best person to lead the party.In a few more years we might have more and better choices for leader than we are currently being offered, they added in a dig at those who have decided to run.Similar petitions from the same group Labour Party members and supporters have received more than , signatures in the past.Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry, Shadow Business Secretary Rebecca Long Bailey and Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer have all said they will consider running to replace Mr Corbyn.A handful of backbenchers including Lisa Nandy and Jess Phillips are also set to enter the race.Yesterday former Cabinet minister Yvette Cooper said she wouldnt run, amid fears she cannot win over Mr Corbyns grassroots army.According to Ladbrokes today, millionaire Remain-supporter Sir Keir is odds on to win.The leftie boss said after losing the election he would step down and allow someone to replace him after more than four years in power.The snap poll saw Labour lose  seats across the country - mainly to the Tories.

title: incredible japanese crystal garden with four koi fish ponds hidden behind ordinary looking nottinghamshire home
story: These photos show the amazing Pure Land Meditation Centre and Japanese Garden which has been created by a former Monk in Nottinghamshire.Koji Takeuchi, who refers to himself as Buddha Maitreya, has lovingly crafted the two-acre wonderland with four fish ponds.Maitreya, , uses the space to teach visitors about meditation and his beliefs in the way of oneness.But the garden may never have happened as the -year-old admitted he never planned on staying when he arrived in North Clton  years ago.He said: “I came here on the way to America from Japan.I had no intention of staying here  years ago when I arrived.“There were a lot of ‘new age seekers’ back then and I became a meditation teacher with a lot of followers from all over the country.“I was in Mansfield temporarily at the time. And we were looking for a place where we could create the garden and when I found this it was just two acres of wild field that I thought could be the right place.”Maitreya began turning the land into a garden because he wanted to “make a peaceful environment and thought back to the gardens in Japan”.It now attracts , visitors every year and has become an unofficial tourist attraction.He added: “Every year it becomes more and more refined. Even in the winter, there’s lots of trimming, racking and cutting to do.“You need to prepare well in the winter for a good summer so there’s lots of work to do.”His principle of ‘oneness’ opposes the ideas of dualism or karma found in many religions from the East.This principle sees everything in the world as “born ine”, with Buddha manested in all people.Maitreya said: I see myself as enlightened because I’m able to see how everything is born ine in this world. With meditation you can realise that.“Nature is magnicent in it’s true form but we do not see it so much in this man-made world.”Maitreya has also created two gardens in India which he visits twice a year.

title: ayia napa teen friend stitch up confession
story: A -year-old psychology graduate, who was with the teenager in Ayia Napa on the night of the attack, said an investigating officer re-wrote her witness statement to make it look like the pair had been drinking heavily earlier.She said: “When I saw my statement in court I couldn’t believe it. No way was it what I had written.”And the -year-old teen’s lawyer told The Sun a close examination of the language used in her statement retracting her rape allegation suggested it was not in her words.Forensic linguistic specialist Dr Andrea Nini said: “The linguistic evidence supports the hypothesis that all or some parts of the statement were not composed by the girl.“They were from a non-native English speaker. The combination of words is not what an educated English speaker would say or write.“What it appears to be is words dictated to her by someone  who didn’t speak English as their first language.” The confession reads:“The report I did on the th of July  that I was raped at Ayia Napa was not the truth. The truth is that I wasnt raped and everything that happened in that appartment was with my consent.“The reason I made the statement with the fake report is because I did not know they were recording  humiliating me that night I discovered them recording me doing sexual intercourse and I felt embarrassed so I want to appologise, say I made a mistake.”Dr Nini said: “It is very unlikely a native English speaker would write ‘report I did’ — it would be ‘the report I made.’“Also an English speaker is more likely to say ‘not true’ rather than ‘not the truth’.“The statement also contains the word apartment which is misspelt with an extra p and is more American than English. ‘Discovered them’ is also not a native English speaker’s phrase.“It’s more consistent with a person who has English as a second language.“Perhaps the most telling is the use of the phrase ‘doing sexual intercourse’ — a native English speaker would say ‘having sexual intercourse’.”The -year-old’s conviction on Monday rests on the validity of the retraction statement, which she is said to have written and signed ten days after the rape.But Dr Nini’s analysis bolsters the well-educated teenager’s claim that the many grammatical errors and spelling mistakes prove it was not written by her.Her lawyer Michael Polak said the statement was written in “Greeklish”.And he insists it was given under duress after almost eight hours of hostile questioning and with no lawyer or translator present — a breach of her human rights.The teenager’s friend, who comforted her as she sobbed and told of the hotel room rape by  Israelis, today insisted the Cypriot police never had any intention of taking them seriously.She added: “It was a stitch-up from the beginning. It felt asthey had made their minds up without even bothering to listen to us.We weren’t taken at all seriously and it felt aswe were being kept in the dark the whole time.”She told of her shock at the way in which her witness statement was taken by an investigating officer.The -year-old, who had been out for a meal with the teenager earlier, added: “There was just me and him in the room and he kept saying to me ‘So you were both drinking a bit that night ’“He was implying that we were drunk and I said that wasn’t the case. He was trying to suggest that it was all our fault because we were drunk. But we weren’t. He was writing my statement as he wanted to interpret it.”Police initially arrested  Israeli men aged between  and  in connection with the attack.But all were later released without charge and allowed home.Police say the teenager invented the rape claim after discovering film of her having consensual sex with one of the Israelis had been posted online.The teenager had started seeing the Israeli a few days earlier and had gone to a hotel room with him after having a meal with her friend.During her trial she told the court they had sex but she asked him to stop when he became violent.A HUMAN rights lawyer has slammed the conviction and said the idea the teen willingly took part in an orgy is a “ridiculous porn fantasy”.Harriet Wistrich, of the Centre for Women’s Justice, said: “I’ve never met a woman who’d consent to .I believe she had sex with one then was treated appallingly by his friends.As I understand there is video evidence of her asking the men to leave the room then they posted what they filmed online, which is particularly offensive.There appears to be a lot of material available.“She confessed under duress. To me the conviction is unsafe.“It’s also tortuous for her having the judge drag it out for so long. I don’t understand his motive.”She said he then pinned her down and his friends burst into the room and raped her.The girl, from Derbyshire, was found guilty of public mischief earlier this week and faces a jail sentence of up to a year and a maximum £, fine when she is sentenced on Tuesday.Yesterday we told how the teenager and her mother called on Boris Johnson to personally intervene to put an end her suffering before she is sentenced. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: iran general qasem soleimani bond rommel lady gaga
story: Loathed yet grudgingly admired by his enemies, Iran’s Qasem Soleimani left this world with the blood of thousands on his hands — including British troops.A master spy chief and military commander, he bolstered Lebanese terror group Hezbollah and backed Syrian despot Bashar al-Assad in his civil war that left hundreds of thousands of innocents dead.Soleimani — commander of the Quds Force, the special forces unit of the regime’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps — was the mastermind behind IED attacks on British soldiers in Iraq and Afghanistan.Ex-Army officer and now Tory MP Tom Tugendhat said in : “Qasem Soleimani has waged a secret war against Britain for years.“For years, Tehran has armed insurgents. Through the Quds Force, it has killed British troops and plotted to assassinate diplomats in Washington DC.“The ayatollahs have nurtured terrorists around the world. Their war has never been declared, but has cost many lives.”That war has now taken another le  —  Major General Soleimani — said to be Iran’s second most powerful man after its Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei.So who was this man who came to be likened to the Scarlet Pimpernel and crime lord Keyser Soze in the film The Usual Suspects A short man, said to have had “understated charisma”, Soleimani was born into a farming family in impoverished Rabor, Iran, in .He had little formal education but would become “a very shrewd, frighteningly intelligent strategist”.Aged , he got a job as a labourer to help pay off his family’s debts and would lt weights after work to bulk up his physique.When the revolution to oust the Shah of Iran broke out in , Soleimani helped organise demonstrations against the monarch.He joined the Revolutionary Guards shortly after it was formed in  and rose through the ranks during the eight-year Iran-Iraq War that left as many as a million dead.Quds was linked to the murder of four Brits in Baghdad in .Likened to World War One, the fighting saw large-scale trench warfare with bayonet charges and Iranians attacking in human waves.Soleimani earned a reputation for bravery, taking part in reconnaissance missions behind enemy lines — often ing with a stolen goat for comrades to slaughter, earning him the nickname The Goat Thief.The conflict’s bloodshed would have a lasting effect on him.In , he led a group of veterans to the scene of a particularly brutal battle from the war and told a cameraman: “One type of paradise that men imagine is about streams, beautul maidens, and lush landscape. But there is another kind of paradise — the battlefield.”It also taught Soleimani the futility of head-to-head warfare. He realised that it was much better to fight from the shadows using proxies where necessary.In , he took command of the Quds Force that specialised in assassinations, arming allies, and later overseeing attacks against coalition troops in Iraq.It would fight for control across the so-called Shiite Crescent — a sweep of terrain with large numbers of Shia Muslims — from Iran through Iraq and Syria to Lebanon.It supported Hezbollah and Palestinians Hamas in conflict with Israel and backed Islamist groups in Saudi Arabia and Bahrain. Though ideological enemies, the US and Iran have at times worked together when their interests aligned.After  , Iran — through Soleimani — provided military intelligence to the US to support its invasion to overthrow the Taliban in Afghanistan. The cooperation, however, was short-lived.When US and British forces rolled into Iraq in  to remove Saddam Hussein, Soleimani had a network of armed militias at his disposal. He unleashed them and IEDs on the Western troops, killing hundreds.Iraq’s former deputy PM Saleh al-Mutlaq said in : “All of the important people in Iraq go to see him. People are mesmerised by him — they see him like an angel.”In , John Maguire, a former CIA officer in Iraq,  said: “Soleimani is the single most powerful operative in the Middle East today.”Soleimani’s tentacles stretched across the globe with attacks in Thailand, India, Nigeria and Kenya.He and his forces played an important role in fighting IS in Iraq. His popularity grew in Iran and he became the subject of TV documentaries and pop songs. He even made Time magazine’s  most influential people list in .Former CIA analyst Kenneth Pollack wrote in the magazine: “To Middle Eastern Shiites, he is James Bond, Erwin Rommel and Lady Gaga rolled into one.“To the West, he is . . . responsible for exporting Iran’s Islamic revolution, supporting terrorists, subverting pro-Western governments and waging Iran’s foreign wars.”Said to be a strict but loving dad of five, Soleimani rose daily at am and was in bed by .pm.Over the past  years, he survived several attempts by Western, Israeli and Arab agencies to assassinate him.In , he took his fight to Donald Trump — personally warning the US President: “You will start this war but we will be the ones to impose its end.”Iran will want a violent reaction but Tehran is terried of fighting a war with the US they could not win and will not start World War Three.Instead, this attack might spell the beginning of the end for the savage regime that has ruled Iran since .They have been crippled by US sanctions and widespread street demonstrations have left the ayatollahs fearful for their survival.President Trump’s bold action will give the protesters, as well as their anti-Iranian counterparts in Iraq, hope that one day they might bring their oppressors down.What are Iran’s military options  Soleimani put in place a network of terrorist proxies, not just in the Middle East but around the world.The most powerful is Lebanese Hezbollah, with tens of thousands of missiles in southern Lebanon, pointing at Israel.They exist to react to a US or Israeli attack on Iran. Butlaunched they would be obliterated by Israel’s massive retaliation.What should Britain do  We do have a dog in this fight. Soleimani’s proxies killed more than , British and US troops in Iraq and Afghanistan in the conflicts there.Our government should now publicly support President Trump’s actions against Iran — and must stand ready to back up the US with military forces and diplomatic ­pressure as the situation unfolds.He added: “We are near you, where you can’t even imagine. Come. We are ready.”Trump took him at his word and a missile from a Reaper drone was unleashed above Baghdad.Death finally caught up with the Pimpernel — a man who had turned the Middle East sands red with the blood of others. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: australia is gods laboratory and people were not actually meant to live there
story: He created it as a continent far, far away where he could house all his experiments that had gone wrong.It was his under-the-stairs cupboard for stuff he wanted to forget about.Like, for instance, the saltwater crocodile. He designed it, built it then realised it was far too savage and bitey to live in, say, Milton Keynes.Or the poisonous redback spider which likes to hide under lavatory seats so it can bite a man’s penis when he sits down to do his number twos. No way could God have that living in Europe or the US.He also made a lot of snakes. Some are very pretty and some are very impressive.But occasionally it all went wrong and he ended up with something that could kill a fully-grown man with one small bite. And again, these could not live in populated areas.He needed a home for all these things, so he made Australia.And to make sure people didn’t go there, he put a huge coral reef on the approaches and filled the interior with a sea of sand that goes on for ever.He even used this remote outpost to house some of his more ridiculous ideas. Stuff he came up with when he was drunk.Like those birds that can’t fly and that otter with a beak.Then you have the kangaroo, which gets about by bouncing, and the koala, which is permanently stoned and catches chlamydiaanyone ever picks it up.For millions of years, this big, sandy cupboard under the stairs went unnoticed.But then along came Captain Cook and now the world knows all about Oz and its stupid, dangerous creatures.Plainly, God is embarrassed. Because he’s decided to set fire to it.It’s been argued the fires raging across the country were caused by global warming or out-of-control barbies.But when you look at the footage, you know something biblical is going on.Those things are huge.Skies have been turned red by the flames. Choking smoke is blanketing millions of acres.Thousands of homes have been obliterated. And people are dying.This has happened before in recent years and there’s no doubt it will happen again.Which means people must accept that Australia isn’t meant for human habitation.Soyou’re reading this down there, please come home.You’ll like it. It never stops raining. And we are better at sport.DURING World War Two, General de Gaulle used London as a base and to say a belated thank you, current president Emmanuel Macron is thinking of giving the city France’s highest award for honour.Needless to say, lots of people are now jumping up and down in Paris saying the Legion d’Honneur cannot possibly be given to London as England and France are “hereditary enemies”.No we aren’t. Germany is our hereditary enemy and not just on the football pitch.France, meanwhile, is just some place we visit to buy cheese and wine.We have no idea what it’s like to fight France because it always surrenders before the battle’s got going.ALL of us begin a new decade with hope in our hearts that it’ll be better than the past one.Not me. This is thanks to two things.Firstly, there’s Libya. Since they shoved a scaffolding pole up Colonel Gaddafi’s bottom, it has been a lawless haven for terrorists and lunatics.Today it’s run by factions of the Judean People’s Front and the Popular Front For Judea, with one backed by Turkey and Qatar and the other backed by the United Arab Emirates and Egypt.There’s going to be a bloodbath. And this is a country less than  miles from mainland Europe.Which means we are going to have to get involved. Becausewe don’t, Russia will.That’s one reason, then, that I fear for the coming decade.The other is that at some point in the next ten years, statistically speaking, I am likely to die.TWENTY years ago, Britain created the perfect argument for not allowing anything to be nationalised or run by the Government.It was called The Dome.Created to mark the end of a millennium, it cost £million and was filled by right-on frizzy haired vegans with things no one wanted to see.There was a plastic human you could walk through, a multi-faith zone and lots of global warming malarkey.Unsurprisingly, it was a spectacular flop.So after a year, it was given away to a property company which turned it into the O, a music venue that now rakes in £million a year. Led Zeppelin had their reunion there.As I’ve always said, governments should put up park benches and run the nuclear submarines.And that’s it. Everything  should be run by the private sector.AS we all trudge back to work, with the fog making our hair frizzy and the puddles reminding us we need some new shoes, we will develop a teeth-rattling hatred for all those celebrities on Instagram who are frolicking in the Caribbean or sipping green juices on a beach in the Males.Amanda Holden. Pippa Middleton. Myleene Klass. Grrrr.Except,you think about it, you and I don’t have to find someone to put sun cream on our back five times a day.We aren’t being eaten alive by mosquitoes. And while a wet pavement isn’t very romantic, it’s better than hopping about, yelping, on a superheated white beach.Also, we will not have dicky tummies from the weird food, bad heads from the cocktails, puffy eyes from the jet lag and the constant worry we’ve been papped while bending over.And what’s more, we didn’t have to spend half an hour at an airport waiting for someone in a high-visibility jacket to take an X-ray photograph of our genitals.TECHNICALLY speaking, the fabulous goal scored by Wolves against Liverpool last weekend was not a goal at all.Because careful examination of the footage showed one of the players involved in the build-up was offside by .mm.It may have been three in the morning. The road may have been empty and the skies clear. And there’s no way you should have to waste a day on a speed awareness course as a result.But technology means we live in a time when there is no grey area. Pity.Many of the kids were explaining how they’d given up meat to save the planet and that Greta Thunberg may be Mrs Jesus.But then, instead of actually going walking, they stayed in the car, running its V diesel engine to keep warm.I WAS asked the other dayI’d be starting the year by doing Veganuary.FINALLY, may I wish everyone a very happy New Year.And extend a big thank you to Jeremy Corbyn and Diane Abbott for making such a thing likely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mullahs ruthless president qasem soleimani
story: He was the truly evil mastermind of the slaughter of countless innocents in the Middle East and had the blood of many British and US troops on his hands.Naturally, there are worries that ­Donald Trump has lit the fuse for fresh ­violence.But Iran and its proxies unleash constant savagery already, until yesterday under Soleimani’s personal direction.He was the architect of ­horrors in multiple countries.He will be mourned only by Iran’s Islamic fundamentalists and, of course, by Jeremy Corbyn and his hard-left anti-American nitwits.But Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab’s reaction was mealy-mouthed too.Of course it would be good for both sides to “de-escalate”.True, “further conflict is in none of our interests”.Mr Raab might have added a full-throated condemnation of Soleimani, effectively the world’s No terrorist, whose victims outnumber those of Bin Laden or al-Baghdadi.Yes, the US should have warned Britain of the drone strike, given the heightened danger now to our  troops in Iraq and Syria. But it had to act rapidly.Iranian reprisals may be inevitable.But standing back hasn’t done the West much good.The mullahs at least now need to factor in a US President who’s more ruthless than the last.Three days ago Ayatollah Khamenei taunted him over the storming of the US embassy in Baghdad. “You can’t do anything,” he sneered.Trump’s put him straight there.  WHAT is this spell Labour’s Jess Phillips casts over Blairites and media pundits  We don’t get it.We do not doubt her hard work, nor that her heart is in the right place.Many naively believe her Brummie accent makes her the true voice of the working-class — this middle-class, grammar-schooled daughter of an NHS executive and a teacher.But that’s not our real beef. It’s the toe-curling, overwrought Commons monologues designed for social media.And the needlessly vitriolic and hysterical Twitter rants.Consider this gem: “The greatest lie ever told is that Boris is likeable, with cut-through outside ­London.” That aged well, as they say.Phillips may yet be Labour’s best hope as leader, God help them.But to be seen as a serious politician, she should start acting like one. IT is obvious the teenager convicted of lying about her gang-rape in Cyprus signed a bogus dictated confession under duress.Its dodgy English smacks of a foreign cop, not an articulate young Brit.The Foreign Office must act. This judicial farce has gone too far already.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lady kitty spencer engaged fashion designer
story: Michael Lewis, who turns  this month, popped the question to the high-end fashion model just before Christmas.The South African-born mogul is worth a staggering £million and is a orced dad of three grown-up kids.A pal told the Daily Mail: She’s been in Cape Town for the holidays and told her mother and the rest of the family.Michael is loved by all of them. title: newspaper bosses slam downing street for trying to seize control of crucial press briefings
story: The system, known as Lobby briefings, allows accredited reporters to quiz the PM’s spokesman in Parliament daily on any pressing issues.But the PM’s team have announced changes which will see the briefings moved to No Downing Street — giving the Government control of who is let into them.Critics have warned the move could damage Press freedom and particularly harm smaller, regional newspapers that do not have an army of political reporters.Society of Editors executive director Ian Murray slammed No for pushing through the changes without any consultation.He said “We understand there are real concerns over access to the new lobby venue at  Downing Street, restrictions on use of mobile phones, and indeed whether this could lead to restrictions on who will be allowed to attend these vital meetings.“The government underscored its commitment to freedom of expression in the recent Queen’s Speech and we would take this to mean a commitment to open government.“There is still time for Number  to consult further with the lobby correspondents’ committee and its members to ensure a sensible new system can be put in place.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour box ticking web of wokery
story: Her cabinet — the perfect balance of men and women, Leavers and Remainers, Oxford graduates and bus drivers’ sons — made politically correct commentators wild with delight.So delighted were they, in fact, they failed to point out a minor drawback to the photogenic new line-up: The PM’s choices were mainly dim, careerist MPs who she picked purely because they ticked the right boxes.The former PM paid a high price for a few days of fawning headlines.She and her useless coterie presided over three years of ision and indecision, only to be unceremoniously dispatched by Boris Johnson and his band of Vote Leavers last summer.But the Labour party hasn’t learned from her mistakes.THERE’S something off about Jess Phillips. If she’s really troubled about racism in the Labour Party, why did she spend the past three years campaigning to get anti-Semitic Jeremy Corbyn into Number  Andshe’s a serious contender for the leadership, why does she spend half her time doing interviews about herself for glossy magazines Yes, personal brand is important. Butthe country is really in the state Jess claims, shouldn’t she be busy fixing it The Labour leadership contender is determined to paint herself as “likeable” and “relatable” but, right now, she’s coming across as a vacuous narcissist. And a slippery one at that.The race to succeed Jeremy Corbyn has so far involved the candidates hamming up their northern accents, trying to out-working class each other, or desperately bigging up their woke credentials to the Press.No one has yet adopted a whippet or done a Layla Moran, the Liberal Democrat MP and potential leadership hopeful who this week described herself out as “pansexual” — attracted to people regardless of sex — but it won’t be long now.For the casual bystander, it all makes for a good laugh. Emily Thornberry’s hysterical claim that her family was once so poor they had to put down a cat sounded so ridiculous in her cut-glass accent, it distracted commentators fromAngela Rayner’s far more legitimate tales of hardship — much to the comical irritation of the latter.For anyone serious about rebuilding the opposition, though, this farcical leadership race is no joke.While Labour contorts itself into a web of wokeness, the Conservatives are quietly cementing their new blue wall in the North.Why  Because outside leftie London and a few university towns, no one cares about tick-box ersity or even the le stories of politicians.Yes, having a “powerful backstory” is usefulyou want to make self-indulgent MPs weepy in the Commons, but it won’t persuade voters that you’re capable of getting things done.And as Boris Johnson proved so decisively last month, getting things done is what counts.The Eton and Oxford-educated Prime Minister looks and sounds nothing like most of the voters in Bishop Auckland or Redcar, but he persuaded them that he was serious about pulling Britain out of a rut.That, it turned out, was enough for an -seat majority.DOMINIC CUMMINGS is spot on: What this country needs is some more nerds.Stuffing the Civil Service full of people who meet gender and ersity quotas is all very well, butyou want employees who bring a fresh perspective, you need recruits who actually think dferently.A tech-obsessed -year-old who skipped university to pursue a career in coding could teach Whitehall’s swarms of humanities graduates a thing or two. And anyone prepared to give up a social le to work for the Government would likely do a far better job than the current civil servants who knock off at pm on a Friday.Bring on the geeks.The Opposition should now take a leaf out of his book.The last election was calamitous, yes, but with  per cent of the vote, Labour is still the second-largest party in British politics.That’s a powerful base for a recoveryit picks the right leader.The challenge is finding that person. As things stand, the field isn’t inspiring.Rebecca Long-Bailey — though a box-ticking superstar — doesn’t have the demonstrable competence that voters are yearning for from Labour.And poisonous Thornberry, who once tweeted a sneering comment about a Rochester home decorated with English flags, will repel patriotic voters.Butthe party is prepared to ditch the ersity nonsense and ignore pious pundits shrieking that the new leader “must be a woman”, the picture is rosier.The unbearably smug Keir Starmer — key player in the doomed People’s Vote campaign — would go down like a ton of bricks in Leave-voting areas.But someone like Dan Jarvis, who has called for Labour to make a “clean break” with the Corbyn era, may just have what it takes.Under Corbyn, Labour proved once and for all that wokeness doesn’t win elections.With the exception of naive students and hipster Londoners, voters don’t much care whether their politicians wear flat caps, headscarves or top hats. They just want politicians who are unafraid to act.So now MPs have a choice.Either they nominate duds with tear-jerking back- stories and shore up their majority in Putney — the right-on London seat which provided the only cause for celebration last time.Or they change tack, abandon wokery, and unearth a strong, competent leader, who might be up to the mammoth task of rebuilding the broken party.It really couldn’t be simpler.PO-FACED leftie commentators must stop laying in to journalists who call Boris “Boris” .They’ve been fighting a losing battle for years. And rightly so.Given Johnson is the third most common surname in the UK, it’s practical – not chummy – to call the Prime Minister by his much rarer Christian name.But, more importantly, the fact our PM is known by his first name on the world stage should be a source of pride to Brits.After three dreary years of Theresa May, Boris’s gravitas and quirky iniduality could hardly be more refreshing.It’s time to embrace it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris under pressure to return from holiday
story: Iranian general Qasem Soleimani was taken out by a drone in an attack at Baghdad Airport last night - bringing the two nations to the brink of war after Iran vowed to carry out crushing revenge.It is believed the PM had no forewarning about the Soleimani strike from Mr Trump, despite signicant UK interests and , military personnel in Iraq and Syria.But U.S. secretary of state Mike Pompeo claimed he discussed the decision to take defensive action to eliminate Qassem Soleimani with Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab.Mr Pompeo added that he is thankful that our allies recognise the continuing aggressive threats posed by the Iranian Quds Force.Mr Johnson has been spending his Christmas break in sunnier climes - but could face calls toto Westminster after MPs blasted the drone strike as reckless.Trump tweeted a picture of an American flag after the attack was announced, and then tweeted Iran never won a war, but never lost a negotiation! this afternoon.Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab has called for calm from both sides.He said this morning: “We have always recognised the aggressive threat posed by the Iranian Quds force led by Qasem Soleimani.“Following his death, we urge all parties to de-escalate.“Further conflict is in none of our interests.”Jess Philips MP, a favourite to replace Jeremy Corbyn as Labour leader, has accused Mr Trump of “playing a game”.She said: “Reckless foreign policy does not show strength. Its not a game.“The consequences of the escalating tensions between the US and Iran are not to be underestimated, not just once again on the civilians in the region but on the whole world.”While Tory backbencher David Jones said the strike could lead to “severe consquences”.He said: “The killing of the leader of Irans Quds Force, Qassem Soleimani, will undoubtedly lead to severe consequences in the region.“It is essential that the Western powers remain mindful of the interests of the ordinary people of Iran.”The US President personally approved the attack that took out Soleimani, the second most powerful person in Iran and leader of the nations military operations in the Middle East.Two missiles fired from a MQ Reaper drone struck Gen Soleimani shortly after he disembarked from an aircraft at Baghdad airport.Iraqi militia chief Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis was also killed in the attack.The Pentagon claimed Gen Soleimani was actively developing plans to attack American diplomats and service members in Iraq and throughout the region.It came days after protesters attacked the US embassy in Baghdad, clashing with US forces at the scene.Amir Hatami, Irans defence minister, has threatened the US with crushing revenge for Gen Soleimanis unjust assassination.While the nations Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said severe revenge awaits the criminals behind the attack.He also announced three days of public mourning.Irans foreign minister, Javad Zar, described the strike as an act of international terrorism.He tweeted: The US act of international terrorism, targeting  assassinating General Soleimani - THE most effective force fighting Daesh , Al Nusrah, Al Qaeda et al—is extremely dangerous  a foolish escalation.The US bears responsibility for all consequences of its rogue adventurism.Last nights strike saw multiple missiles hit two cars carrying Gen Soleimani and several officials with Iranian-backed militias as they were leaving the airport.Iraqi state television said that five Iraqis and two guests had been killed. Pictures showed burning debris on an airport road.He was known as The Shadow Commander by his enemies, spending most of his career as a recluse and a spook.The Quds Force, tasked with carrying out operations beyond Irans borders, shored up support for Syrias Assad when he looked close to defeat in the civil war raging since  and also helped defeat ISIS in Iraq.Former CIA officer John Maguire said Soleimani was the single most powerful operative in the Middle East.Soleimani had survived several assassination attempts against him by Western, Israeli and Arab agencies over the past two decades.The Trump administration designed Soleimanis Quds Force as a terror organisation in April last year.He was the second most powerful person in Iran behind the Ayatollah Ali Khamenei at the time of his assassination.He was hailed as a national hero by many in Iran and was awarded the Order of Zolfiqar medal, Irans highest military honour, last year.

title: jeremy corbyn condemns us for airstrike on iranian general
story: The Labour boss said the killing of general Qasem Soleimani at Baghdad Airport was “extremely serious”.Mr Corbyn tweeted: “The US assassination of Qasem Soleimani is an extremely serious and dangerous escalation of conflict with global signicance.“The UK government should urge restraint on the part of both Iran and the US, and stand up to the belligerent actions and rhetoric coming from the US.”Mr Corbyn’s blast comes after Labour MPs accused the US President of being “reckless”.It is understood Boris Johnson was given no forewarning about the strike – despite signicant UK interests and , military personnel in Iraq and Syria.The US President personally approved the attack that took out Soleimani, the second most powerful person in Iran and leader of the nations military operations in the Middle East.Mr Trumps only personal response so far has been to tweet a picture of a US flag without comment.Two missiles fired from a MQ Reaper drone struck Gen Soleimani shortly after he disembarked from an aircraft at Baghdad airport.Iraqi militia chief Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis was also killed in the attack.The Pentagon claimed Gen Soleimani was actively developing plans to attack American diplomats and service members in Iraq and throughout the region.It came days after protesters attacked the US embassy in Baghdad, clashing with US forces at the scene.Amir Hatami, Irans defence minister, has threatened the US with crushing revenge for Gen Soleimanis unjust assassination.Jess Philips MP, a favourite to replace Mr Corbyn as Labour leader, has accused the president of “playing a game”.She said: “Reckless foreign policy does not show strength. Its not a game.“The consequences of the escalating tensions between the US and Iran are not to be underestimated, not just once again on the civilians in the region but on the whole world.”Mr Corbyn has previously faced criticism for his relations with Iran after he appeared on the nation’s state TV for fees of up to £,.He was slammed in June last year as pathetic by then Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt after calling on the government to provide “credible evidence” that Tehran was behind attacks on British oil tankers.The Labour boss had claimed: Britain should act to ease tensions in the Gulf. Without credible evidence about the attacks, the Government’s rhetoric will only increase the threat of war.”

title: ex army chief blasts corbyn for backing our enemies
story: Colonel Richard Kemp accused the Labour boss of being a “mouthpiece” for the Iranian regime - after Mr Corbyn slammed “belligerent” Donald Trump for taking out general Qasem Soleimani at Baghdad Airport.He told SunOnline: “[Jeremy] Corbyn can always be relied on to back our enemies over our allies and that is why he sides with Iran over the US.“He was previously a paid mouthpiece of the same regime in Iran as Soleimani served by delivering acts of terrorism around the world.”Mr Corbyn has previously faced criticism for his relations with Iran after he appeared on the nation’s state TV for fees of up to £,.He was slammed in June last year as pathetic by then Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt after calling on the government to provide “credible evidence” that Tehran was behind attacks on British oil tankers.Col Kemp’s comments come after Mr Corbyn condemned President Trump for bringing Iran and the US to the brink of war, following threats of crushing revenge by Tehran.He tweeted: “The US assassination of Qasem Soleimani is an extremely serious and dangerous escalation of conflict with global signicance.“The UK government should urge restraint on the part of both Iran and the US, and stand up to the belligerent actions and rhetoric coming from the US.”It is believed the PM had no forewarning about the Soleimani strike from Mr Trump, despite signicant UK interests and , military personnel in Iraq and Syria.But U.S. secretary of state Mike Pompeo claimed he discussed the decision to take defensive action to eliminate Qassem Soleimani with Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab.Mr Pompeo added that he is thankful that our allies recognise the continuing aggressive threats posed by the Iranian Quds Force.Mr Johnson has been spending his Christmas break in sunnier climes - but could face calls toto Westminster after MPs blasted the drone strike as reckless.Col Kemp, a former COBRA chief and Britain’s commander in Aghanistan, has begged Boris to honour the Special Relationship and back Mr Trump over the attack.He told SunOnline: “The U.K. government should publicly back President Trump’s strike and also be ready to give the maximum possible military and diplomatic support to the US as the situation unfolds.“Soleimani ordered the killing of many British as well as American troops in Iraq and Afghanistan and it is right that he should have been made to pay the price for his murderous activities everywhere.”

Daily Star Online has found the iconic British brand appears to be making little noise about closures of at least  stores.Pictures have been surfacing on social media showing the signs plastered in the windows of stores across the country. This comes a year after the once mighty retailer collapsed into administration and five years after it first fell into administration in . The outlets affected are in Leeds, Reading, Plymouth, the Bullring in Birmingham, Worcester, Bury St Edmunds, Grimsby, Plymouth, Nuneaton and Bury. HMV fans have been sharing their shock on social media after finding the closing down signs with no warning from the firm.One Twitter user wrote: “Went into Birmingham today and found out that HMV is closing. I’m bare sad right now.”Another wrote: “Gutted that @hmv_Nuneaton are closing down at the end of the month. Greedy landlords strike again, I fear!” “My local HMV is closing I repeat the HMV in Meadowhall is closing. This is disgusting, said another. Another comment included: “Just found out youaposre closing and I canapost deal! #hmv #meadowhall #sucks.” While another person seems to have discovered their store is moving rather than closing down. “My heart dropped when I saw the Closing sign, then realised they’re just moving, sad to see the store go but glad Plymouth will still have a HMV!”, they wrote. One gutted HMV fan has even voiced fears the closures are part of a “company wide review” across the country. “Is HMV closing down UK wide  Thought it was just our local one,” they wrote. “HMV in Leeds city centre also had store closing down posters up today. Sounds like a company wide review.”  Canadian firm Sunrise Records appeared to have saved the brand when it purchased  stores and secured , jobs in February. But it dumped  of HMV’s stores – including its flagship Oxford Street in London – leaving them to close and resulting in  redundancies. Sunrise Records chief executive Doug Putman said at the time of the takeover he was delighted to acquire the most iconic music and entertainment business in the UK. The -year-old Canadian added: ”By catering to music and entertainment lovers, we are incredibly excited about the opportunity to engage customers with a erse range of physical format content and replicate our success in Canada. We know the physical media business is here to stay and we greatly appreciate all the support from the suppliers, landlords, employees and, most importantly, our customers.  One retail consultant on Twitter suggested earlier this week that the closures were a result of short-term lease deals running out with no agreement. Graham Soult replied to one concerned HMV fan: “More likely the end of short-term lease deals agreed when the takeover occurred a year ago, and a failure to agree a new arrangement. “Youaposre right that there seems to be a flurry of closures just now, though!” Mr Putman told the Mirror in October that he believed the high street can thrive as he prepared to open Europe’s biggest record store, a ,sqft branch of HMV in Birmingham in a former IKEA store. Staff at Birminghamaposs Bullring branch were told The Vault opening would signal the closure of their store. Those who know the business say that, while the Bullring store has been taking more money than The Vault, its overheads are considerably higher. Employees told local media they had not been given a definitive closing date to pull down the shutters inside the Bullring, but the consensus was that it was likely to be at the end of January. The closing down sale that will end the companyaposs days as a core Birmingham city centre business. The new The Vault site is more on the fringe of the city centre, inside the former Toys R Us turned IKEA collections store below NCPaposs High Street Car Park, Dale End.  The entertainment giant used to have a branch in the  Pavilions shopping centre next to Waterstones on Birmingham High Street, but that complex was closed in May  to make way for  the worldaposs biggest Primark  which opened on April , . A statement issued on behalf of the Bullring said the shopping centreaposs owner Hammerson had helped HMV to reclocate in the autumn. “We can confirm that the HMV store at the Bullring is due to close. HMV recently opened Europeaposs largest entertainment store with Hammerson, HMV Vault, at Birmingham’s Dale End. We continue to offer a great range of technology and entertainment at Bullring  Grand Central including Game, Sky and within John Lewis and Selfridges, and look forward to introducing a new offer to the centre in due course.” One of the stores set to close is in Grimsby, where a closing down sale is now underway at the store, although details about the reason for the closure is not yet known.  It is also not yet knownany of the  closing stores are relocating, although Plymouth appears to be one of these. HMV has been contacted for comment. Company history HMV is due to celebrate its centenary in . Its first shop was opened on July ,  at  Oxford Street in London by legendary composer Sir Edward Elgar . Born in Lower Broadheath near Worcester, Elgar was the first professor of music at the University of Birmingham for three years from .  The company became a major part of Britainaposs high streets as vinyl sales soared in the s, s and s. It survived the switches from vinyl to CDs and VHS cassettes to DVDs, but the post iPod and iPhone decade of - began to pose major new challenges in terms of how people consumed music and films. Some , jobs were at risk in January  when HMV called in administrators. It was bought by Hilco UK for an estimated £ million in April, . The company sold  per cent of physical copies of music in the UK in  and  per cent of all DVDs and Blu-ray discs.  But when it collapsed again on December , , some , jobs were again put at risk. In February , the boss of Canadian label Sunrise Records saved the company but axed  stores. Tory ministers want families to dig their gardens this weekend and plant their redundant trees, rather than send them to the tip. If thereaposs no option to plant your trees, ministers also suggest checking whether councils have a special collection service - though that could prompt criticism, given the Tory cuts to councils in recent years. Or ministers suggest a recycling service that could use the trees to build flood barriers or turn them into path chippings or soil. The call is a boost for the Mirroraposs Million Trees campaign which aims to plant a million trees over five years. Today, just % of the UK is covered in trees, compared to the EU average of %. We have waged our fight with A Trillion Trees, a joint venture of the world’s largest conservation charities – WWF, BirdLe International and Wildle Conservation Society who are together fighting deforestation and to restore forests around the world. As Britons prepare to strip their festive trees before twelfth night and Epiphany on Monday, Environment Minister Rebecca Pow urged households to consider keeping their trees. She said: “Millions of families around the UK celebrated Christmas with a beautul fir or spruce tree in their home, but when the decorations are taken down it’s important that we dispose of trees sustainably. “If you have a tree with its roots still attached, then replanting your Christmas tree is a great way to reduce your carbon footprint and help our efforts to plant more trees.” According to the British Christmas Tree Growers Association, between six and eight million real Christmas trees are sold in the UK every year.If not reused or recycled, real trees can end up in landfill. Sending eight million trees to the local dump would cost about £million. A typical six to seven foot high Christmas tree is between  and  years old. Nordmann Firs are the most popular in British homes, making up % of those sold, with Norway Spruce making up  to %. According to the Committee on Climate Change, the Government’s statutory advisers on the climate crisis, the UK should have .billion new trees by  to meet its net zero carbon target. But last year just , hectares of its ,-hectare yearly target were planted. The Government said real Christmas trees which were not replanted can be shredded into chippings, which can be used in parks or woodland areas.

title: jeremy corbyn urges uk stand
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn demands UK stand up to belligerent US after Irans Soleimani killedThe outgoing Labour leader was among a host of left-wing figures urging the UK to condemn Donald Trumps administration - which spoke to Britain today after launching an airstrike on Iranian General Qasem SoleimanShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political EditorSophie Morris:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsGeneral Qasem Soleiman was killed by a US air strike at Baghdad airport in Iraq " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn today urged the UK to stand up to the belligerent US after the assassination of top Iranian general Qasem Soleimani. The outgoing Labour leader said there must be restraint on both sides but warned the airstrike was an extremely serious and dangerous escalation of conflict in the Middle East. And he said further conflict can only bring further misery to the region after the  Iraq War, which he opposed. It came as Britain called for calm on both sides with UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab speaking to US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo earlier today. But holidaying Boris Johnson - who reports suggest was not told about the attack in advance - was urged to get off his sun lounger to deal personally with the crisis. And despite calls for calm, defiant Donald Trump tweeted a photo of the US flag and tweeted: Iran never won a war, but never lost a negotiation! Labour MP Stella Creasy called for an urgent recall of the UK Parliament. She tweeted: That parliament not due to meet until Tuesday surely unsustainable in such circumstances. General Qasem Soleiman was killed by a US air strike at Baghdad airport in Iraq ordered by United States President Donald Trump . He was head of Tehranaposs elite Quds Force who spearheaded military operations in the Middle East. Mr Corbyn said: “The US assassination of Iranian general Qasem Soleimani is an extremely serious and dangerous escalation of conflict in the Middle East with global signicance. “The UK government should urge restraint on the part of both Iran and the US, and stand up to the belligerent actions and rhetoric coming from the United States. “All countries in the region and beyond should seek to ratchet down the tensions to avoid deepening conflict, which can only bring further misery to the region,  years on from the disastrous invasion of Iraq.” Tensions between the UK and Iran have mounted in recent months, leading to a dramatic military stand off in the Strait of Hormuz over the summer. The seizing of the ,-tonne British-flagged tanker, the Stena Impero, by the Iranian revolutionary Guard in July triggered a diplomatic crisis between London and Tehran.  That followed the detention of the Iranian tanker Grace , which was carrying . million barrels, off the coast of Gibraltar earlier that month. Now todayaposs killing risks unleashing a fresh wave of revenge in the volatile Gulf. Iranian Defence Minister Amir Hatami, the top commander of the elite Quds Force, vowed a crushing revenge against all those involved and responsible for his assassination. And Iranaposs Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei warned that severe revenge awaits the criminals behind the strike and announced three days of national mourning. Boris Johnson was criticised for staying personally silent in the hours following the attack - after spending the new year on Mustique, a Caribbean holiday island for the rich and famous. Angela Rayner, expected to run for Labouraposs deputy leadership, tweeted: The PM must at least get off his sun lounger to make some kind of statement on the US attack killing the senior Iranian general and the escalating dangerous situation between Iran and the USA.Leaving it to the hapless Dominic Raab will not suffice. Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said: “We have always recognised the aggressive threat posed by the Iranian Quds force led by Qasem Soleimani. “Following his death, we urge all parties to de-escalate. “Further conflict is in none of our interests.” But several of the UKaposs Labour Party leadership hopefuls responded to the strike by hitting out at the UK stance - and warning against military escalation. Rebecca Long-Bailey tweeted: With this assassination, President Trump is pushing us to the brink of another disastrous war that would cost countless lives, further destabilise the region and make us all less safe. Our government should help de-escalate tensions, and we must resist any rush to war. Emily Thornberry, the shadow foreign secretary vying to succeed Mr Corbyn, said Mr Raabaposs statement was insufficient and criticised the PM for having pathetically unopposed Mr Trumpaposs decision to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal.  The Foreign Officeaposs call for restraint today is too little and far too late, in the wake of such a brazen, unlawful and provocative attack, she said. As the drumbeat for war with Iran grows ever louder, and the first shots are being fired, we must fight through the UN to stop this conflict, and fight in our Parliament to stop British forces being put in harmaposs way in the service of Donald Trump. Labour leadership contender Jess Phillips tweeted: “Reckless foreign policy does not show strength. Itaposs not a game. “The consequences of the escalating tensions between the US and Iran are not to be underestimated, not just once again on the civilians in the region but on the whole world.” Lisa Nandy added: This is a very dangerous moment.  years after the catastrophic decision to go to war in Iraq violence still rages every day. World leaders must stand up to Trump. The last thing we need is another all out war.  Former Army reservist Clive Lewis said: This violent escalation in an already volatile region is a mistake  should not be compounded by UK govt support. I call on the PM to condemn this cowboy action  turn immediately to our international institutions to try  de-escalate any war with Iran. I shed no tears for Soleimani, he was a cruel man who unleashed suffering for many. But violence begets violence, especially without a thought out military strategy. I know this from my time in Afghanistan. The UK must now lead in being a broker for peace. And Keir Starmer said: This is an extremely serious situation. There’s a clear danger of further violence and escalation in the Middle East. We need to engage, not isolate Iran. All sides need to de-escalate tensions and prevent further conflict. The US Secretary of State thanked Mr Raab in a phone call for recognising the aggressive threats posed by the Quds Force in his statement, according to US spokeswoman Morgan Ortagus. Mr Pompeo was also said to have stressed that the White House remains committed to de-escalation.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA single mum forced to rent a rundown property after losing her house just before Christmas has turned it into a beautul home on a shoestring budget. Lauren Grfin, , from Kent, was dealt a huge blow when her landlord told her he would be selling the property so she would need to move. Her mum, who was her acting guarantor, was then made redundant. This meant the mum-of-two was left in hell as she was only able to afford a property in terrible condition. Lauren found a house in the worst state ever but was determined to give it a makeover in time for her and her two sons to enjoy at Christmas.She revealed the incredible transformation in Facebook group DIY on a Budget where members show the fruits of their labour while spending as little cash as possible. Lauren posted in the group: Living in private rented as a single mum Iaposve always used my mum as a guarantor.  aposThis October I was given notice to move out due to landlord selling up just after my mum got made redundant. Unable to rent anywhere  I had to take on the only place I could get through someone I knew that was in the worst state ever barely even habitable with two boys.  Itaposs been hell on earth and real testing times turning this place around quickly to make the nicest home possible for my boys in time for Christmas. Lauren told FEMAIL it said it took around two months to carry out the transformation. She painted the rooms in the propertyaposs bleak and depressing rooms and added new furniture including a table and chest of drawers in the living room. Blued LED lighting was added to the staircase, which had its banisters repainted, and to the bathroom which also had new laminated floors installed. Lauren replaced the dirty carpet in her bedroom with a new grey one and soft furnishing additions such as new cushions, curtains and rugs completed the new look.She said: Thereaposs still a long way to go and far from perfect, but today I am proud of how far I have come on a tight budget. Doing all of the work just myself and my mum.  Finally feeling less depressed and more like this is our home. Have done all three bedrooms now and almost finished the living area, kitchen and bathroom just been far too busy to take anymore pictures so far. Her talents have not gone unnoticed by members in the group.

story: NewsThousands of monkeys being bred in misery across UK as home pet trade exposedEXCLUSIVE: Celebrity owners and a desire to stand out on social media are seeing an explosion in the trade in pet monkeys which is legal despite terrible psychological and physical suffering for the poor monkeysShareCommentsByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  JAN NewsJoey" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThousands of monkeys are being bred in homes across the UK in a squalid but legal suburban pet trade. Trapped indoors, some never leave their tiny cages and suffer devastating illnesses ranging from depression to brittle bones. Some are so badly neglected they need to be put down. Rescue workers say their popularity as pets is rising thanks to celebrity owners and a desire to stand out on social media. Tens of thousands of primates across Europe are in desperate need of rescue but are left to suffer as sanctuaries are now full. Rachel Hevesi, of Wild Futures monkey sanctuary in Looe, Cornwall, said: “The UK trade, which is still legal, leads to huge psychological and physical suffering. “Every time a celebrity is pictured holding a monkey we wonder what this will do to the demand. We have to turn away mon­­keys in desperate need as our sanctuary, and others, are full.” Breeding and selling small monkeys such as marmosets and tamarins is legal with a licence under the Dangerous Wild Animals Act. But welfare experts say as few as % are actually licensed. The exact number of primates kept as UK pets is unknown. In  it was estimated at up to , but given the inc­­reased popularity, it could now be higher. Capuchins are among the most popular. Two years ago they would fetch £, but they now sell online for just £ due to a surge in home breeding. Capuchin Joey was imported from South America with legal papers. But once in his UK home he had no access to direct sunlight, was alone for  hours a day and was unable to exercise.  He ended up with rickets and also rocked so obsessively he developed an open wound at the base of his spine. Primate expert Dr Ben Garrod, from the University of East Anglia, said: “Primates do not make good pets. Keeping them drives their extinction in the wild. “It’s hard enough for a zoo to keep a healthy population let alone someone who, even with the best intentions, simply doesn’t have the time, money or expertise.”  Dr Garrod said  European countries have some form of ban on pet primates and called for them to be made illegal here.He also called celebrities such as Justin Bieber , who share pictures with pet mon­­keys, “morons”. The RSPCA, which has urged action for years, said it received calls about monkeys most weeks.

title: veganuary best worst veggie versions
story: NewsVeganuary: The best and worst veggie versions of fast food classicsAfter Greggs released a no-steak vegan bake yesterday, we test the new arrivals in all things vegan fast food from KFC, McDonald’s, Costa, Subway, Pizza Hut and more to see which pass the meat-eater taste test...ShareCommentsByPoppy Danby:,  JAN NewsA selection of vegan fast foods " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter Greggs released a no-steak vegan bake, we check out the arrivals in vegan fast food from KFC, McDonald’s, Costa, Subway, Pizza Hut and more to see which pass the meateater taste test... Waitrose Asian inspired BBQ Mushrooms with Sticky Rice How much: £. What’s in it: Aromatic sticky rice is partnered with marinated and roasted portobello mushrooms, pak choi and pickled vegetables in a spicy chilli and garlic sauce. Taste verdict: I was so keen to try this dish that I burned my mouth in excitement. But it was definitely worth it. The tangy sauce and thick strands of mushroom partnered perfectly and were almost meaty in texture. In fact, there wasn’t mushroom for improvement. Rating:   I’d definitely miss out on meat to enjoy this meal again.  MS Beetroot and Carrot Bourguignon How much: £. What’s in it: MS have made their bourguignon with root vegetables to be served with a caullower mash. Taste verdict: One of new items available in the Plant Kitchen vegan range, the Beetroot and Carrot Bourguignon was filled with huge chunks of root veg and the ready meal was certainly filling. The creamy mash went down a treat too! However, there was a slightly sweet after-taste to the dish due to the beetroot sauce, which was a little off-putting. Rating:   Tasty enough but meat can’t be beat for this classic.  Pizza Hut Pepperphoni pizza How much: £. for a regular-sized pizza. What’s in it: Pea protein and Viole vegan cheese provide the perfect basis for this plant-based pizza. Taste verdict: Bubbling with “cheese” as I opened the box, this pizza looked like any peperoni fan’s dream. The taste was good but was overshadowed by the rubbery texture of the topping, which left it feeling a bit stodgy. If you fancy a pizza then I’d look where for a slice of the action. Rating:   Only real pepperoni can cut the crust when it comes to a Pizza Hut takeaway.  Subway Meatless Meatball Marinara How much: £. What’s in it: The new sub features the same delicious marinara sauce as the original. However, the plant-based alternative is stuffed with vegan cheese and plant-based meatballs. Taste verdict: The Meatball Marinara is one of Subway’s most iconic sandwiches, so it was a bold choice to create a plant-based alternative for Veganuary. However, this was just as good as the original. The meatless meatballs had a nice, authentic texture and the sauce was so good that my only criticism is that I would have liked more. Rating:  : Definitely not a sub standard attempt at a meat-free alternative.  Wagamama Vegan “tuna” How much: £. What’s in it: The strange sounding dish is made with dehydrated watermelon which is sliced, seared and served hot to give the texture of tuna sashimi. Taste verdict: This concoction tastes just as odd as it sounds. Surprisingly, on first appearances, the hot watermelon looked just like regular sushi but just one bite had me screwing up my face as my brain struggled to come to terms with what I was eating. And, at nearly £ a bowl, there’s definitely something a bit fishy about this idea. Rating:   I wouldn’t bother with this. Butyou still fancy going vegan then Wagamama’s have a range of other dishes, such as a Yasai Katsu Curry or Kare Burosu Ramen, which are plant-based without being too peculiar.  KFC Vegan Burger How much: £. What’s in it: Casting their signature chicken aside, KFC use an Original Recipe Quorn fillet for their vegan burger. This is then coated in the restaurant’s special  herbs and spices and served in a sesame bun with fresh lettuce and vegan mayo. Taste verdict: As a big fan of The Colonel’s chicken I was a little sceptical about whether KFC could work in vegan form. But the Quorn fillet was seasoned perfectly and aside from a slightly chewy texture was more than a bit moreish. Rating:   A finger lickin’ good opportunity to replace meat this Veganuary.  Costa Vegan Smokey Ham  CheeZe Toastie How much: £. What’s in it: The coffee chain boasts that it’s plant-based snack is made with Quorn smokey ham and coconut cheese sandwiched between two slices of vegan bread. Taste verdict: This was a simple offering from Costa as part of their new vegan range. Unfortunately, there wasn’t much filling, so the toastie was a little thin and the Quorn was hard to taste. But the vegan cheese was soft, melty and hard to distinguish from any other piece of cheddar. Rating:   If Costa added a little more filling then the original cheese and ham toastie would be... well... toast.McDonaldaposs Veggie Dippers How much: £. What’s in it: Both vegan compliant and gluten free, McDonalds’ Veggie Dippers are made with red pepper, rice, sundried tomato pesto and split peas. They’re also coated with light and crispy breadcrumbs.

story: NewsYoung woman who found out boyfriend was cheating took her own le months laterEmily Elliott, , of New Hey Road, Huddersfield, was discovered at her home months after she split from her boyfriend. They rekindled their relationship shortly before she died on June .ShareCommentsByRobert Sutclfe:,  JAN NewsEmily Elliott took her own le months after she found out her boyfriend had been messaging other women " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young woman took her own le just months after she found her boyfriend had been cheating on her, an inquest heard. Emily Elliott, , of New Hey Road, Huddersfield, attempted to take her own le just weeks after she split from partner Shay Doyle, who she met at Huddersfield University. She recovered and they rekindled their relationship, but a few months later Emily was found dead at home.Mr Doyle discovered her body on June , several months after they had initially broken up because Mr Doyle had been contacting another girl through Facebook , Bradford Coroneraposs Court heard.The two former University of Huddesrfield students had a turbulent relationship, assistant coroner John Broadbridge heard. Mr Doyle, of Wilmslow, Cheshire, gave evidence in front of Miss Elliottaposs family including her father Stan and mother Zarah Khilji as well as her brothers Fox and Jacob. He explained they had met initially as friends at university around  . Miss Elliott, a former Greenhead College student, had studied Sociology but failed her course after the first year while Mr Doyle studied a Graphics Design course. The court heard she was a very attractive, sociable young woman who had lots of friends and worked in bars and clubs such as The Warehouse, Camel Club and Mavericks. She had also worked previously at Tesco in Westbourne Road, Marsh. Mr Doyle was questioned by Mr Broadbridge about how their relationship began. He said: After eight-to-nine months there was flirting and getting a bit closer to one another. She lived with me and three of my friends in Huddersfield for a while, a couple of months. I would say we had a good relationship though we had the odd argument like any other couple. We split up. I had been texting another girl through Facebook. The coroner asked him: Can you accept that Emily was extremely distressed when she found out about this relationship and, to say the least, reacted badly  Mr Doyle agreed that was so. He was then questioned about Miss Elliottaposs attempt to take her own le in February . Mr Broadbridge asked: How soon did that occur after your separation  Mr Doyle, who admitted he was not good with dates replied: A friend told me. A month or two after it happened. Mr Broadbridge told him the attempt took place on February  and said: So it would not be a month, it would be a matter of weeks or days  Mr Doyle said: I found out a month or so after it happened. He said they had blocked one another on social media in the aftermath of his cheating but at the end of March had rekindled their relationship, though by now he was living in Wilmslow. Mr Doyle said: Things were going well, we talked about having children together.  But the court heard that on Thursday,  June, Mr Doyle got no response when he tried calling her so he sent a text message to one of her best friends, Kimberley Knight, askingshe had heard anything to which she replied that she had had some weird messages from her. Mr Doyle caught a train to Huddersfield Rail Station and then a cab to her home which she shared with her father. He broke down in tears as he told how he found the front door open. He said: I went upstairs and Emilyaposs bedroom door was closed. He opened the door and found her unresponsive. He said he screamed for help, dialled  and attempted to perform CPR before paramedics took over. The coroner asked him: Was there any clue in those few days that she was desperate, that she might harm herself  Mr Doyle replied: No. The coroner said: Were you shocked at what you saw  Mr Doyle: Yes. After hearing a wealth of evidence about Miss Elliottaposs history of mental health problems, previous overdose attempts and heavy drinking the coroner concluded that she had taken her own le.
