title: Aaron and Andrew are pair of crackers
story: IT was one of the best kept secrets in history.Even his we did not know the course. His close friends and running colleagues tried every trick in the book to ascertain the route for the annual Castlewellan Christmas Cracker, but uncharacteristically lsquoThe Prophetrsquo remained tight-lipped and taciturn. The usual platitudes and prosaicisms were thrown out by way of appeasement, but they threw no light on the course that has been in the planning since January .Phrases like, lsquothere is something for everyonersquo, lsquothere will be a few good climbsrsquo, lsquowe will go through a field or tworsquo and lsquoI still have a few ditches to clearrsquo served only to add intrigue and mystique to the potential route.From am, parking spaces were snaffled up as the growing crowds made their way to collect their numbers, totally unaware of what lay ahead, another unique characteristic of this now iconic event.When we go to races we usually know what lies ahead as it will be the same as the previous year mdash not so with this one.This led to great speculation at registration and the passing of spurious rumours, lsquoIrsquove heard it is Foxes green firstrsquo, lsquoBunkerrsquos Hill is the first climbrsquo, lsquothe gates at Niall Kingrsquos place are open and that can only mean one thing!rsquoThose unwise enough to listen were tormented, while the more sanguine took it all in their stride realising that what would be would be.The atmosphere in the GAA club was electric and filled with excitement as every little corner became a changing space and in the middle of all of this Stevie Rice had set up a stall and had created a monopoly on udderrmint ndash an essential for the discerning runner.With space at a premium, one team had pre-booked the VIP changing facilities in Ned McCartanrsquos front room. Here the gracious, ebullient and effervescent host provided valet parking, bespoke carb-rich pre-race food, handed out warm fluffy towels and proffered words of wisdom and encouragement. The * package was completed with optional dog therapy ndash petting Socks.The  entries were snapped up in a few weeks, such is the popularity of this event among the NI running fraternity.Running in pairs is far from commonplace in what is largely an inidual sport and this certainly brings a welcome new dimension in that you are only as good as your partner and an ill-conceived or sentimental choice could see you standing waiting at the top of a hill, the bottom of a hill or at the finish.The secret lies in getting the right partner, one you know you can work with and whose running skills complement your own ndash a lesson that has still to be learned by a number of this yearrsquos participants.While the event is a great opportunity to dress up, socialise and enjoy the wonderful scenery that Castlewellan has to offer, the racing at the sharp end of the field is seriously fierce.From the moment they were set on their way at the bottom of the Circular Road, the cream rose to the top as the leading teams thundered their way through the town at breakneck speed.Getting good road position at the front is essential for the leading men and women.In , Newcastlersquos Lynch and Hanna were clear winners with a minute and a half to spare over Johnston and Scott of Mourne Runners, with McMullan and Stephens, from the host club, a further  seconds back in third.These three teams were paired once again, but had to settle for second, third and fth respectively. With Hanna in the form of his le and regularly representing Ireland in the hills and Lynch coming off a superb  minute k at the Seeley, they were the in-form team and pre-race favourites.However, favourites do not always win and on this occasion it was Aaron McGrady from East Down and his partner Andrew Barrington, originally from Oban in Scotlandwho emerged victorious.The pair, who run and race together for Victoria Park Harriers in London, were among a group of leaders along the Crow Road.As the course rose steeply after the Moorish Tower, the pair was second behind Lynch and Hanna as they hurtled through the fields towards the Bannanstown Road.As was the case in , the climb over the Playrock Hill would prove decisive and the eventual winners managed to pull away and open a winning lead.However, McGrady admits that once they hit the front, they had to work very hard over the last three miles as they knew the quality of the team chasing them.When asked about the course, the winner said that it was very dferent to previous years, was far less muddy than anticipated and despite the steep hills offered great opportunities for hard fast running.Overall, he considered it to be a well-planned and carefully balanced route. McKinstry was always in contention, but his partner suffered terribly and put paid to their chances of the win ndash they would finish fourth overall.Beechmount Harriers claimed the ladiesrsquo team prize with Sarah Laverty and Catherine Diver finishing in an excellent th place overall ndash all that training up the hill in Falls Park paid off.They were joined on the podium by Hannah Somani and Georgina Wileyand Amanda Perry and Denise Logue .In the mixed category there was a great win for Shalene McMurray and David McNeilly who were th overall and comfortably clear of their nearest challengers and club mates Mari Troeng and Frank Cunningham. Karen Wilton and Andrew Wills of Jog Lisburn completed the mixed team podium.There were male, female and mixed category winners dotted throughout the field and these are highlighted in the results file available on the Newcastle AC website . Well done to everyone who won a prize.Some of the fancy dress was simply amazing and added greatly to the sense of fun that is central to this race. Special mention to the Power family who once again dressed to impress and the three sheep bleated their way around the course under the ever-watchful eye of Bo Peep, the Newry AC crew who were came as the cast of lsquoIrsquom a Celebrityrsquo, but regrettably failed to get out of there and had to complete all nine miles and the Grant family and their friends who looked lsquoCrackingrsquo for the Cracker.Costumes came in all shapes and sizes with superheroes galore and even the odd beach ball shoved up a T-shirt for maximum effect.Before we draw the curtain on this event there are some necessary closing remarks.Firstly, we have to mention some of those who were lsquopale facedrsquo as they crossed the finish line.Among this number were Connaire McVeigh, his brother Brian McVeigh, Noel lsquoWonderwallrsquo Gallagher , Dee Murrayand Patrick Higgins who it would seem invented a new shade of grey.While all of these are notable and honourable mentions, there can only be on winner of such a prestigious accolade.The worthy recipient is none other than Dominic lsquoMad Dogrsquo McGreevy, who by his own admission was lsquoclean burstedrsquo by evergreen Jim Brown before they even left the show field.Whilst cogitating the next day with McVeigh, he noted that there was a distinct lack of climbing in the opening mile which considerably reduced his chances of the overall win.Of course, all of this is pure conjecture, passed on to me by others who were better placed to judge. As these pale faced warriors finished, I was probably getting a drink at Stephen McMullanrsquos pop-up tavern in Leitrim.The day was a great success due to the hard work and planning that took place. Course designer McCrickard would like to thank his incredible team that spent the best park of two days marking ndash Francie McAlinden, Audey McVeigh , Aidan Brownand Donal Ward.Thanks also to the entry management and registration team who did so much work in creating and continually updating and modying the team ndash no small task, the marshals from our own club and neighbouring clubs, the lead cyclists from Shimna Wheelers and Kilmegan CC, the motorbike riders, Robert and Paddy, the finish team and the presentation party ndash too many to name inidually, but you all know who you are.In conclusion, the feedback from the , that completed the course was amazingly positive and a great time was had by all. Rumour has it that lsquoThe Prophetrsquo was observed entering the park this morning with a bill hook and a bow saw ndash preparations must be underway for ..prettyPhoto

title: Boyle family celebrates as Tom marks milestone 100th birthday
story: A DOWNPATRICK man celebrated his th birthday before Christmas.Tom Boyle, the townrsquos former postmaster, became a centenarian on December .He was congratulated by a steady stream of relatives and well-wishers who called to the home he shares with we Maria in a low-key celebration.He is third local man to celebrate his centenary during .Felix Burns, from Rossglass, turned the big  in May, and was followed in August by Roddy Maguire from Downpatrick.All three received congratulatory card from the Queen. As the men were all born citizens of Ireland, they each also received a letter and euro, cheque from Irish President Michael D Higgins mdash a special financial bounty given by the Irish State known as the Centenarian award.Born in Warrenpoint before moving to Omeath and onwards to Belfast, Mr Boyle came to Downpatrick as postmaster in .According to his we, he can boast of having retired on two occasions, first from Downpatrick Post Office when he was in his s and again when he was in his s, as he helped Mrs Boyle out in her role as sub post office mistress in Strangford.When asked what he ascribed his long le to, quick as a flash, he answered: ldquoBreathing.He added: ldquoI canrsquot really explain how I managed to get to this age as Irsquove done nothing special. I just take one day at a time and then the next day. They seem to add up and then you are .Mr Boyle is the last of his family of three brothers and two sisters. He followed his fatherrsquos footsteps in working for the Post Office.He and his we have been married for  years and while they have spent over  years living in Downpatrick, they lived for around  years in Killough, which they remember as a particularly happy time.Parents to five children mdash Desmond, Ciaran, Damian, Philip and Roisin mdash the couple have eight grandchildren mdash Emma, Maria, Madeline, Ciara, Enya, Meabh, Grace and Thomas..prettyPhoto

title: Down GAA lodge planning application for £7m centre
story: A FORMAL planning application has been lodged to develop a major new poundm GAA sports centre in Ballykinlar.Details of the ambitious multi-million pound proposal were outlined last November with the proposal including four floodlit pitches. including the current pitch owned by Ballykinlar GAC.The major investment proposal also features changing facilities for players and officials and a multi-use sports area.Other key features of the development mdash which will be financed via a cocktail of funding mdash include spectator seating for , fans at one of the new pitches which it is hoped will in future host club championship games.Plans have also been unveiled for a fitness studio and floodlit walking trail around the new development covering just over  acres of land.The proposed development is also set to become the new administrative base for Down GAA in the county with access to the highly ambitious proposals via Ballykinlar GACrsquos Commons Road base.Described as a major ldquogame changer for football, hurling and camogie at county level, it is also hoped that the new facility located in a stunning location will provide a catalyst for additional investment in Ballykinlar village, helping boost its social and economic regeneration.A number of detailed reports required by planners have already been carried out ahead of the formal planning application lodged shortly before Christmas. It is hoped that construction work can get underway next year.Senior GAA officials have been in discussions with the Ministry of Defence to secure  acres of land to help pave the way for the new development which will be used by all Gaelic games codes in Down.The proposed development is being described as a ldquomassive boost for gaelic games in the area and a key part of a new vision for the sport in Down. It is also hoped that it will provide a signicant resource for the Ballykinlar club and local communities.Down GAA officials say the Ballykinlar project forms part of a new vision for the county and hope that it will lead to success on the field.Former county chairman Sean Rooney, who recently stepped from from his post, said that it will be a ldquophenomenal achievement to deliver the exciting new development.He said the new centre will provide Down GAA with a dedicated, permanent base which is does not have at present, explaining that for many years, the county board has been hiring ious facilities, highlighting the importance of preparing teams for major competitions properly.GAA officials hope that the new centre of excellence will provide a  for future success at county level for footballers, hurlers and camogs.Ballykinlar has been described as the ldquoideal venue as training and matches can take place virtually every day of the year due to excellent ground conditions, with GAA officials excited by the proposals for the future.Ahead of the formal planning application being lodged by the Resolve Planning and Development Innovation Factory, extensive work was carried out, with GAA officials grateful for the support of the Ministry of Defence in advancing the project.The planning application will be scrutinised by Newry, Mourne and Down Council planners..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick pair in soroptimist success
story: TWO St Maryrsquos High School students have taken part in the annual Soroptimist International public speaking competition held recently.Annie McMullan, was awarded second place and Nora Maguire was third in the final which was held in Saintfield High School.Anniersquos topic was entitled lsquoTo bee or not to beersquo, a speech about the importance of bees in the world.She was commended by the judges for her use of comic timing and her excellent delivery. Norarsquos speech was entitled lsquoExperience is the teacher of all thingsrsquo and she was complimented on her content and use of humour.The aim of the event is to encourage girls to play a more prominent part in public le, to improve the art of communication and to encourage girls to develop the skill to speak effectively and develop self-confidence and personality..prettyPhoto

title: Esther meets ‘Chatty Man’
story: A BALLYGOWAN woman who runs a Slimming World group has rubbed shoulders with Channel Four chat show host Alan Carr.Esther Croskery, represented the group at a prestigious award ceremony held at Birminghamrsquos International Convention Centre before Christmas.Esther was delighted to get a chance to meet Alan and says it was the perfect end to a fantastic year for the Ballygowan Slimming World group.Celebrating the grouprsquos weight loss success over the last  months, she said: ldquoThe members at our Ballygowan group make me burst with pride. Not only have they seen big changes on the scales, many have improved their health and completely changed their lives.ldquoFor many people, taking that first step into a Slimming World group takes a huge amount of courage, but theyrsquore always certain of a warm welcome.ldquoBeginners love being introduced to our flexible eating plan which means hunger is always kept at bay while losing weight.ldquoWhen you join a group and come along each week, members support each other with motivation, cheering each other on and boosting each others confidence, as well as sharing tips and ideas.Esther, who runs her Slimming World group from the village hall each Wednesday, continued: ldquoWatching people grow in confidence each week and take on new challenges they didnrsquot think possible amazes me.ldquoI feel proud of the small part I play in supporting people to achieve their dreams and to celebrate alongside them when they do. Last year was our th year and we are supporting more people than ever to achieve their dreams and are excited about what  also has in store.ldquoFor anyone thinking of taking that step to lose weight and improve their health this New Year I believe that joining a local Slimming World group is the best way for people to adopt new habits and make long-term changes.ldquoAt the Ballygowan group theyrsquoll discover a whole world of support to help them achieve their dreams and stay slim for le mdash with lots of fun along the way too.Alan, who presents comedy chat show Chatty Man on Channel Four, said it was great to meet Esther at the event.He said he was left in awe at the dference Slimming World makes to peoplersquos lives.He said: ldquoI met so many people who had transformed their lives and it was clear how much the support they received, meant to them.ldquoEvery one of them spoke passionately about how they couldnrsquot have made those changes to eat more healthily and become more active without the support of consultants like Esther and their group every week.Alan added: ldquoI left the awards feeling so uplted and positive, I wish I couldrsquove bottled that Slimming World feeling.To find out how you could get that Slimming World feeling call Esther on   or visit www.slimmingworld to find your nearest group..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C January 1%2C 1980
story: DRINK DRIVERS mdash The RUCrsquos pre-Christmas blitz on drunken drivers has been a major success in Down District, with road traffic accidents over the holiday period hitting an all-time low.For the first time in years the district has avoided a fatal accident over the Christmas period and, indeed, the accident figures were so low that police and hospital casualty units report one of the quietest years on record.A police spokesman confirmed it was the most peaceful Christmas period for a long time. In Downpatrick alone, there were only three accidents mdash all minor mdash over the five-day Christmas break, and the story was the same in virtually all other stations in the district.A spokesman for Downe Hospital said that only two people were admitted due to road accidents between Christmas Eve and December .Therersquos no doubting ghat the big lsquoDonrsquot Drink and Driversquo clampdown has been responsible. Most areas of the district were saturated by breathalyser units and the then normal police patrols followed up with vehicle checkpoints which netted more culprits.The police spokesman said: ldquoChristmas may be over, but the clampdown will go on. Statistics show that the holiday period was one of the safest on the roads for many years. With a similar clampdown on speeders and careless drivers, our roads could be much safer.DOWNPATRICK mdash The Inglis biscuit firm was fined a total of pound at Downpatrick Court for selling underweight packages of biscuits.The magistrate, Mr Wishart Mills, strongly rebuked the firm, commenting: ldquoThe amounts shown on the package should be there. Itrsquos a serious matterthey are not.The Belfast firm admitted ten separate counts of selling underweight packets bought by a Department of Commerce inspector in Strangford on August .A representative for the Department of Public Prosecutions said the firm had a ldquostring of previous convictions, four for selling underweight biscuits, including a conviction at Downpatrick Court in .A defence solicitor explained that the biscuit factory was undergoing changes to comply with EEC regulations. The firm accepted the packets were underweight. The change in operation meant the biscuits had to be weighed dferently.ldquoA mistake had been spotted ad the firm took all reasonable steps to dispose of the underweight packages. However, this one box managed to get out by mistake, the solicitor added.ldquoThe magistrate heard that the bath of biscuits were taken off the market the next day.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Cinema enthusiasts in Ballynahinch and district wonrsquot have to travel farthey want to see all the top films because a new Millbrook Movie Show begins in the townrsquos hotel next week.Starting on Tuesday night the Millbrook Lodge Hotel intends showing many of the top films mdash and they have Burt Reynolds starring in Mean Machine as their opening film.Seats in the weekly feature film night will be only pound mdash andpatrons cut out the advert in this weekrsquos Recorder they will get a % reduction.The men behind the Millbrook Movie Show are owner Jim Maguire and his friend, Robert Emerson. With no cinema serving Down District mdash the nearest are in Comber, Belfast, Bangor and Banbridge mdash they hope to cash in on what is a steady attraction.ldquoItrsquos a new outlet for the people of the town and district, said Robert. ldquoWe offer top films at a cheap price and car facilities are available before and after the two-hour shows.ldquoWe intend bringing recent prevent feature films mdash perhaps some of the big ones that locals have missed mdash and showing them in comfortable surroundings.NEWCASTLE mdash Newcastle Technical College wonrsquot get its much-needed additional accommodation in . In its allocation of funds for new capital works, the Department of Education is giving preference to schemes at primary and secondary schools, rather than further education centres such as technical schools.A strong bid was made in November to the South Eastern Education and Library Board by local representatives Mrs Ethel Smyth and Mr Jarlath Carey to have greater priority given to the proposed conversion of the former Homa Engineering factory in Newcastle.The Board voted against the motion by  votes to  when preparing their list of most essential schemes to be started this year and it seems that the Department has agreed with them.CROSSGAR mdash A large number of children and adults attended the switching-on ceremony of the Crossgar Christmas tree.Mr Denis Cahill extended a warm welcome to all present and the clergy taking part were the Rev James Lamont and Fr Gabriel Maryand the Rev Alan Parkhill, who led in prayer.After the signing of the familiar carols, led by the choir of St Colmcillersquos High School, under their conductor, Mr E Kerr, the lights were switched on by Tom OrsquoPrey and Lesley Eynon, followed by a visit from Santa Claus, who distributed gts of fruit and chocolate to all the children.MOURNES mdash A new -bed youth hostel in the Mournes is to get financial backing from Newry and Mourne Council. The council is to hand over a cheque for pound to the Youth Hostel Association of Northern Ireland.The Association is also to receive pound, from the Department of Education in grant aid and hopes to get pound, from other government bodies, as well as raising pound, itself.In a letter to the council, the Association pointed out that the Kinnahalla Youth Hostel at Spelga, near Hilltown, was in jeopardya proposed new reservoir to supply water to part of Belfast and North Down was carried out.To celebrate the golden jubilee of thte Association in Northern Ireland in , it proposed erecting a hostel at Dinnywater. During the past year the Association has raised pound, towards the project.The council was told that the Mourne Mountains were the greatest tourist attraction in the area and that another youth hostel there was badly needed.KILMORE mdash Crossgar Accordion Band, under their conductor, Mr James Ellison, rendered selections of Christmas music at a united carol service in Kilmore Parish Church on the Sunday before Christmas.The combined choirs of Kilmore and Lissara led the congregation in the singing of well known carols and the lessons were read by Misses Maree Greer and Carol Maude, Mrs E M Morris, Mrs G Simpson, Messrs Matthew Cuffey and Mark Killen, Austen Nelson and Lord Lowry.Miss Ruth Maude presided at the organ and the offering was in aid of Save the Children Fund. After the service supper was served to the congregation, for which Mr T J Hewitt ed thanks.PORTAFERRY mdash A new rector has been instituted to serve the parishes of Ballyphilip and Ardquin in Portaferry. He is the Rev J P O Barry, who had five yearsrsquo service as curate with St Markrsquos Parish, Dundela.The institution was carried out by the Rt Rev George Quinn, Bishop of Down and Dromore. After the service the congregation were invited to tea on the parochial hall in Ann Street.HORSE RACING mdash Bookmakers in Downpatrick arenrsquot looking forward to next Saturday when horses owned by two Downpatrick brothers could cost them a small fortune.The horses, owned by Noel and Leo McGrady, have become the scourge of betting shops in the county town as they chalk up win after win in what has become their most successful season and next Saturday will see of them in action again.DARTS mdash Sean Morgan lted the first major trophy of the season in the Downpatrick and District Darts League when he won the Guinness inidual tournament. The competition was held at the Slaney Inn, Raholp, in font of a capacity crowd..prettyPhoto

title: Loggerhead turtle making waves back to full health
story: JC, the little loggerhead turtle currently being rehabilitated at Exploris Aquarium in Portaferry, has taken his next step to being released back into the wild.Following a year of specialised care since being found washed up on a Co Donegal beach last January, JC was recently moved into the ocean tank at Exploris, which will provide him with a more stimulating environment.It will also give him a lot more room to swim and drive around with other animals as well as competing for food mdash all essential to ensure that he has a successful introduction back into the sea.The current inhabitants of the ocean tank at Exploris Aquarium include black reef tip sharks, trigger fish, stingrays along with a iety of large marine reef fish.The turtle made a surprise appearance on the Irish coastline when he was found by the Johnstone family who named him Julius Cesar.Peter Williams, curator at Exploris Aquarium, has worked closely with JC since his arrival.He explained about the turtlersquos journey back to good health.ldquoWhen JC arrived at the aquarium, the turtle was in a critical condition and we were unsure on whether or not it would pull through, he said. ldquoThankfully with expert around the clock care, it wasnrsquot too long until JC was out of the woods.ldquoOnly weighing a mere .kg when he arrived, JC has been feeding well on a iety of fish and invertebrates. We are now happy to report that the turtle weighs almost kg and his shell is almost cm.Peter added: ldquoWe are very pleased with the progress JC is making here at Exploris Aquarium and we have no doubts that this will continue. Hopefully next year we will be able to release JC back to the ocean.Exploris Aquarium also works to rehabilitate sick and abandoned seals which are found on the Northern Ireland coastlines..prettyPhoto

title: Nurses set to strike twice next week for better pay
story: LOCAL nurses are set to strike again next Wednesday and Friday as part of the continuing campaign for better pay and increased staffing levels.On Thursday, December , nurses based at the Downpatrick hospitals braved atrocious weather conditions as they manned the picket line outside the entrance to the Downshire Civic Centre at the Ardglass Road in the town.Staff based at the Downe and Downshire hospitals took part in the protest and were joined by Ambulance Service staff, with their colleagues at all the provincersquos hospital taking part in the -hour strike.Hours before the industrial action commenced, Sinn Fein, DUP, UUP, SDLP and Alliance politicians met the head of Northern Irelandrsquos civil service, David Sterling, and Department of Health permanent secretary Richard Pengelly to try to avert the strike.In addition, the politicians also sent a joint letter to the Secretary of State, Julian Smith, expressing collective support for the restoration of pay parity.No progress was made and the strike went ahead as planned.Now local nurses are preparing to go back on strike next week, with the news confirmed recently by the Royal College of NursingrsquosNorthern Ireland Director, Pat Cullen.According to the RCN, nursesrsquo pay in Northern Ireland has fallen in real terms by % over eight years, aggravating a shortage of about , nurses, a vacancy rate proportionally higher than England and Wales.Health workers want pay parity with their counterparts in England, Scotland and Wales. Health unions agreed a .% three-year pay rise for NHS staff, excluding doctors, in  but the deal did not apply to Northern Northern because of the absence of devolved government.Nurses based at the Downpatrick hospitals were among an estimated , from the Royal College who went on strike for the first time in the unionrsquos -year history the week before Christmas.The one-day stoppage marked a serious escalation after weeks of industrial action by other healthcareworkers. RCN nurses were joined by their Unison colleagues on the picket line in poor weather, buffeted by wind and rain.Northern Ireland has the worst hospital waiting lists in the UK, according to figures from the Department of Health with some , people waiting for appointments. On average, there is a four-year wait for knee and hip operations.The December  strike mdash which placed pressure on a range of hospital services and resulted in planned out-patient procedures and appointments being cancelled mdash placed increasing pressure on politicians restore the power-sharing assembly and executive at Stormont.During the industrial action, nurses did provide cover to ensure chemotherapy, intensive care and palliative care services at hospitals remained in place, while district nurses only attended emergency calls. A small number of domiciliary home calls were also cancelled.According to the South Eastern Trust,  outpatient appointments were cancelled and , others were not scheduled due to the recent industrial action.Ms Cullen said the local health service could not survive another winter, without improved pay and conditions for NHS staff.ldquoThe health service is in crisis, the senior RCN official continued.ldquoWe have , people on the waiting list for a hospital appointment and we have a severe nursing shortage, which is highlighted by the Nursing and Midwery Council figures.ldquoOur members have been out on strike to fight for patient safety and to improve conditions for everyone. Quite simply, we cannot afford to wait any longer to address the problems facing the health service. Another winter like this and the health service will be irreparably damaged..prettyPhoto

title: Olympic bid for Border Cup glory
story: BALLYNAHINCH Olympic get a shot at redemption when they confront Rathfriland in todayrsquos eagerly-awaited Border Cup final showdown at Seaview.Last yearrsquos cruel penalty shoot-out defeat to all-conquering Crumlin Star in the final has plagued Olympic ever since and now is the time to put things right.Olympic have proven all the doubters mdash who predicted that they were one-season wonders mdashseriously wrong and they are back in the final on merit.Wins over Holywood , Bloomfield , Dromara Village , Dunmurry Recand Shankill Unitedhave made the rest of the league sit up and take notice for the second year in a row.Liam Sloanrsquos side are also going strongly in the Premier Section and are unbeaten after nine games. However, all that will count for nothing when they walk out at Seaview this afternoon.Sloan knows more than most that cup finals are all about what happens on the day and no amount of preparation or game planning can change that.With Olympic what you see is what you get.There are no prima donnas in the squad and they have all bought into the team ethos ndash one in, all in.The Olympic boss has made a few shrewd signings since last season and the new faces have gelled well with the group.Olympic may have lost top scorer Niall Murray to Crumlin Star, but Stefan Mason has proved more than a capable replacement.Stefan, now in his second spell at the club, joined from Drumaness Mills at the start of the season and his insatiable appetite in a main strikerrsquos role has endeared him to all.He is a nightmare for all defenders as he never stays still and is continually looking for space. He is not afraid to shoot and is also as brave as they come, adding a bit of physicality to his game in recent times.He has formed a perfect partnership with the under-rated Chris McNamara and the potentially explosive Nathan Jones mdash and all three are reliable matchwinners.Paul Dickson, another new signing, first came to prominence a few years ago when he starred for Noel lsquoDixiersquo Deanrsquos emerging Temple Rangers side that famously reached the semi-finals of the Clarence Cup.Since then he has played for Ballynahinch United and Saintfield United, but his adventurous style of play from the back has given Olympic an added dimension to their play.He has been joined in the squad by Anton McGrattan, a stylish midfielder, who gets up and down the park with ease and who is not an easy player to dispossess or put off his game.Basically, the rest of the Olympic remains the same and therein lies the secret of their success. Goalkeeper Ryan Walsh, a member of the Amateur Leaguersquos representative team, has enhanced his growing reputation this season and he rarely makes mistakes.Manager Sloan has the luxury of being able to play a number of formations at the back. Jason Noade is a colossus in the centre of defence with either Stevie McGoran, Connor Reid, Dickson or the highly-rated Dalton Tate flanking him.Midfield enforcer Ryan Noade,he is fit, can also play in the back four, but he, brother Stevie, Shane Murray and workaholic Ryan Molloy make up a formidable midfield unit with McGrattan able to cover any position in the engine room.Olympic have serious strength in depth and James McClean, Aaron McLean, Adam McClean, Simon Marmion, Jack Roddy, Josh Fennell, Darren Lyons and Reece McConnell are all ready to step up to the markthey are required.However, standing in Olympicrsquos way is one of their own, now making Rathfriland tick.Andy Kilmartin started out at Olympic as a raw teenager with immense talent.He signed for Glasgow Celtic before moving to Glentoran, Portdown and Glenavon where he won an Irish Cup medal.The martinette is now pulling Rathfrilandrsquos strings alongside Newcastlersquos Jonathan Scannell and Downpatrickrsquos Peter Telford and Ruairi Fitzpatrick.Olympic know these players inside out and given a fair wind, they hope to blow Rathfriland away in what promises to be an intriguing final.Coincidentally, this will be Telfordrsquos fth Border Cup final appearance, but he has yet to appear on a winning side.He has lost three finals with Downpatrick FC and one with Kilmore Rec and is hoping that it will be a case of fth time lucky this afternoon..prettyPhoto

title: Out of Africa book looks at richness of sharing humanity together
story: THE latest book by Downpatrick author Dr Stan Papenfus has just been published.Out of Africa has a title that he plagiarised from Pliny, the ancient Roman writer, who wrote: ldquoOut of Africa always something new.The subtitle of this book, lsquoSharing our livesrsquorsquo, derives from an African proverb mdash lsquoA person is a person through peoplersquo. It an also be translated as lsquoA person becomes a person through peoplersquo.The signicance of this proverb becomes ever more clear in the being and becoming of the three story tellers who share their lives with Dr Papenfus.Each one of them expresses and explores the truth of their own experiences and each one has their personal reality confirmed by the events and situations that unfold. In this telling, they also create how they who are and who they can be.Gabriel Makamanzi, from Zimbabwe, specically sees his own problems and dficulties belonging not merely to himself, but to the whole community in which he lives.This community is brought alive for us as he describes it and he expects us to relate it to our own problems and dficulties. In this way, he says, we all work together to discover our own creative freedom and realise our potential.Gabriel notes that le is for love. And yet, without honesty, our personal and shared reality is not reality at all.Instead, it is a pretense and those of us who pretend he sees us ldquoliving meaningless livesrsquorsquo.Dr Papenfus says: ldquoGabrielrsquos story challenges us, as it challenged him, to recognise our own poverty and despair, only to realise the spiritual power and richness of sharing our humanity with each other.The next exploration of time experiences is by Zakele Makaluza, from South Africa. He talks about his arrogance and his refusal to heed the warnings given to him by his ancestors, as they appear to him in his dreams.Zakelersquos experiences also refer to his relationship with bees, but not ordinary bees, rather with those ldquogentlemen of the honeyrsquorsquo sent by his ancestors to remind him of his duties to others, especially to members of his own clan.Dr Stan said: ldquoZakele, in his exploration of his experiences, brings us to an awareness of our own integrity or lack or integrity, in ourselves and in our relationship with others. He realises his potential only after he is persuaded of a certain truth, which he has been denying nearly all his le.ldquoIt is his cousin who opens up his awareness and tells him also that this was an experience that were lsquodestinedrsquo to share.The last person giving his testimony in the book is David Maganda, from Uganda. He came from a very big family and when his father died he was left to fend for himself, especially with regard to earning enough money to pay for his education.Even as a young boy, he secretly took a train from Uganda to Kenya, hoping to make enough money to sponsor his schooling. But, instead, he found himself on a ldquomission impossible as he calls it.He and his friend found themselves stranded and virtually penniless in the city of Nairobi. They had no place to stay, no work and no friends.How are they toto Uganda  They found themselves walking for mile after mile, along long and dusty roads, depending for their very survival on the kindness and pity of strangers. After living through a fierce storm and other hardships, they eventually arrived at the Kenya-Uganda border. Here, in their completely squalid state, they were interrogated by the police, who eventually let them cross the border.Arriving back in Uganda, they miraculously met Davidrsquos friendrsquos sister, who was working at a trading station. And so, at last, they find themselves able tohome.Each of their families get them to promise never again to engage in such a mad exploit. And yet within ten years he finds himself stranded once again, this time in the Sudan.Here, however, he is able to make do by earning money and pursuing some schooling and eventually being presented with a graduation certicate. Because of the particular school he attended, he was also able to become a confirmed Christian. However, he discovers, through his interaction with others, that his Christianity is only lukewarm.Through many strange encounters he eventually learns how to accept Christ into his very heart of hearts.As a result of this, he preaches the good news of salvation and in Northern Sudan he is even beaten and imprisoned.As time goes by he meets his we, Gillian, at a theological college in England. Today, David lives in Belfast and is only a lay preacher, but also someone who teaches others how to explore and discover the meaning of their lives and with others, how to realise their potential.Out of Africa is available on loan from Downpatrick Library and can also be bought from amazon..prettyPhoto

title: Seals prosper in Strangford Lough
story: STRANGFORD Lough is proving to be a popular nursery for grey seals.The largest sea inlet in Ireland can boast having  pups born in its waters during last autumn, the most since records began almost  years ago.The National Trust, which records the number of wildle visiting the area, revealed there were  adults in the lough at the peak of the breeding season last year ndash something of a turnaround for the protected species.In the early s records show that only around six or seven grey seals were born in the area each year.Lead ranger at Strangford Lough Hugh Thurgate say several factors have contributed to the growth in numbers.He said: ldquoThe boom reflects the burgeoning population in Scottish waters which is pushing the population down the North Channel and into the Irish Sea and seals are being forced to seek out new places to breed.ldquoThe shelter of Strangford is a strong draw for seals on the look-out for alternative spots to relax on shore during the breeding and moulting seasons.Mr Thurgate agrees that Strangford Lough is just the place for them.He added: ldquoThe seals are looking for a safe and protected place to raise their young ndash somewhere that provides protection from the elements and is relatively free from disturbance ndash which Strangford Lough offers.ldquoPups are quite vulnerable. Seals give birth on the beach andyou get stormy weather, tidal surges and high spring tides, high pup vitalities can occur because seals are unable to thermo-regulate properly.ldquoSo,you have calmer conditions pups are going to have a better chance of survival.The mild lough islands of Strangford are a favourite spot for the seals to haul out in large groups, known as rockeries, now a regular sight for boat users.Mr Thurgate, who has worked on Strangford Lough for two decades, has seen the population steadily rise.He said: ldquoWe starting counting seals in . And in , rsquo and rsquo the Trust recorded extremely low numbers of grey seals. Then slowly but surely they increased and by the mid-noughties there were around .ldquoThen it jumped quite signicantly and by  we had  pups for the first time. In  they went passed  mdash we actually recorded  that year.However, the common seal, cousin to the grey seal, isnrsquot enjoying the same kind of success on the lough.The changeable summer weather, followed by deluges and floods in November, proved challenging and the total population is now alarmingly low at under ..prettyPhoto

title: Students continue to excel on school’s 60th anniversary
story: THE th anniversary prize distribution at St Malachyrsquos High School, Castlewellan, was held before the Christmas break.The principal and staff were honoured to be joined by the guest speaker, Sister Teresa Clancy, who was one of the first members of the teaching staff when the school opened its doors in .Sister Teresa remained in St Malachyrsquos for her entire teaching career and served as vice-principal, demonstrating her commitment to the children and families of the area.The principal, Mrs Orla OrsquoNeill, began by congratulating the prize winners on being recognised for their admirable achievements throughout the past year.She told them: ldquoSt Malachyrsquos High School is all about fulfilling potential. We balance the academic and pastoral needs and wants of the students so they can achieve successful outcomes. Tonight affords us the opportunity to focus our attention on those many achievements of our students, our staff and our community.ldquoI am very privileged and honoured as principal to be a part of this wonderful school that has produced such high calibre students, who have all moved on from success to success and who represent all that is great about inclusive Catholic education.ldquoThe curriculum that we offer our students is the same as all post primary schools. However, we provide this in a schoolcommunity where all young people can learn and achieve together.Mrs OrsquoNeill stated with pride that St Malachyrsquos students continue to excel on the academic front with GCSE students once again producing record breaking results, with % of students achieving A*-C grades in five or more subjects and  students achieving seven or more A*-C grades and many achieving nine,  and  GCSEs.She said the quality of results had increased with many students securing several A* and A grades across the board in a wide range of subjects.Turning to A-Levels, she results attained ldquocontinue to be up there with the best.She said % of students three A-Levels at grades A*-C. A third of all grades were A* or A with % leaving St Malachyrsquos with three good A-Level passes.She said the percentage of St Malachyrsquos students going on to university was well above the Northern Ireland average.Guest speaker Sister Teresa captivated her audience, in particular the students who found her words inspirational.In a good-honoured address full of anecdotes and words of wisdom she recalled her daysas teacher and vice-principal fondly. Her nostalgic tone showed the audience just how much pride she took in being a part of the foundations of St Malachyrsquos as a teacher in .She spoke of the beginnings of St Malachyrsquos High School and how the amalgamation of the boysrsquo and girlsrsquo school came about.She referred to former principals and teachers and her memories of how the St Malachyrsquos community came to fruition since . She congratulated pupils, past and present for their outstanding achievements of the past year and beyond.She called St Malachyrsquos a ldquohighly motivated school with everyone working with and for each other.Her words of wisdom were to the pupils themselves. She advised them to talk to someone. She said she understood the demands of modern le and the stress it can have on young people. She advised the audience to reach out and reminded them that they were not alone.She reminded everyone to live by the gospel message and to treat others as they would like to be treated..prettyPhoto

title: Ulster Rugby stars muscle in to help at Downpatrick foodbank
story: ULSTER Rugby and Phoenix Natural Gas came together to bring some festive cheer and extra support to a food bank and a youth centre in Downpatrick.Senior team players Nick Timoney, Jack McGrath and Kieran Treadwell helped out with packing and distributing food parcels for families across the area at the Fountain Foodbank at their busiest time of the year.Volunteer co-ordinator Shirley Lennon said she was delighted to have some extra muscle.She added: ldquoWe have been overwhelmed by the generosity of the local community for our foodbank appeal which helped support over  families across Downpatrick over Christmas.ldquoThe volunteers were fantastic and we were very glad to have had a team of strong helpers who made light work of moving so many Christmas parcels.A second team of Ulster Rugby senior team volunteers, Stuart McCloskey and Billy Burns, made their way to Patrician Youth Centre to take part in a rugby mini skills session with  pupils from Our Lady and St Patrickrsquos Primary School, before answering questions from the young people attending.Yvonne Maguire, manager of the Patrician Youth Centre, praised the players for their involvement.She said: ldquoFor many of the children this was their first time getting involved with rugby but the players put everyone at ease, getting involved in the session themselves and just encouraging them all to have fun mdash which they did. We would like to say a big thank you to Ulster Rugby and Phoenix Natural Gas for this fantastic opportunity.The sessions were organised as part of the Ulster Rugby and Phoenix Natural Gas LineOut programme which sees both organisations working together to make a real dference for communities across the Province.Jonathan Martindale, executive director at Phoenix Natural Gas, added: ldquoMaking a genuine dference for people and communities is at the heart of the LineOut Programme for ourselves and our partners at Ulster Rugby and we are delighted to have been able to offer our support to Fountain Foodbank and Patrician Youth Centre this Christmas..prettyPhoto

title: Young Rory celebrates superb year
story: AN eight year-old pupil from Our Lady  St Patrickrsquos Primary School in Downpatrick, has been kicking up a storm in the world of karting.Rory Armstrong has set the sport alight this year and he practically cleaned up at the age annual motorsport awards night in the Roe Park Resort last week.The young flyer was crowned Northern Ireland champion, Ulster champion and Northwest champion in his class. He also received a special award for most race wins from any competitor across all classes in Northern Ireland.Rory also competed in the Southern Ireland Championship, narrowly missing out on a series win, finishing second overall.The icing on the cake has come with Rory now preparing to go to England next year to compete in the highly competitive DRS series run by Formula One driver Daniel Ricciardo..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. It only became compulsory for front seat passengers in the early s, and in rear seat passengers around the time I began to drive.Rapidly the UK moved from a culture in which most people in cars were not restrained into one in which almost everyone wore a belt..ev-modals .modal.in .modal-dialog .photo-article-notier-default .ev-widget .photo-article-notier-default .photo-article-notier-default .ev-widget p @media.photo-article-notier-default .ev-widget p #jp .main-content .ev-widget#sticky-footer .sticky-footer-banner .photo-article-sticky-footer-banner .photo-article-sticky-footer-banner p @media@media#sticky-footer .desktop-sticky-footer_text,#sticky-footer .desktop-sticky-footer_button #sticky-footer .fluid-container #sticky-footer .mobile-sticky-footer_button Deaths and injuries were reduced radically.The other huge change that I notice since then is adherence to  mph speed limits.I remember well the casual way in which these limits were ignored, albeit with occasional moments when police patrols would be found at the edge of such a  mph zone.Drivers routinely sailed into a  mph zone travelling at mph or even  mph.I recall the sense of bewilderment that the wide Newtownards Road outside Stormont had such a limit, when a  mph or  mph limit seemed more appropriate.Now, like most other drivers, I am well used to travelling at exactly  mph along that stretch and it seems a reasonable speed.In the late s and the s, around  people died each year on average on Northern Ireland’s roads. Traffic levels have risen by a multiple of more than . since then, which means that such a fatality rate applied to current traffic levels would result in perhaps  deaths in Northern Ireland each year.Last year there were  deaths, the joint second safest year since records began in .The average number of deaths over the last decade has averaged only .A spate of tragic deaths in recent days shows that, as the authorities keep telling us, one death is one too many.But we should not make that point so forcefully that we lose sight of the stunning — simply stunning — progress that there has been in making our roads far safer.Ben Lowry: A conversation about Northern Ireland with Professor Brendan O’Leary Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"At least  people are alive each year who would otherwise be deadwe had not made such strides in safety.As well as greater adherence to speed limits and seat belt laws, there are many other reasons for the decline,Motorists are better trained, better aware of the risksand better aware of the penalties for drinking or killing someone.Cars are much better built and have to be maintained to a safer standard . Roads are better designed and have better markings.Even so, I can think of several measures that could help to drive deaths down closer towards zero.• Dashboard cameras within cars. They are already used to keep down insurance premiums of young folk, butthat was expanded, fewer and fewer people would dare to drive badly.• A  mph speed limit in streets with housing. The  mph limit is too high on such residential roads. Some years ago I was discussing this with an old school friend and we both agreed that  was too high for streets with lots of parked cars. We were travelling at well below  and put our theory to the test and began to increase our speed up towards the  limit and then stopped before reaching it, because it was obviously too fast with cars on either side. Yet lots of drivers still tear down such roads at that speed or higher.• Greater use of average speed cameras in  mph zones. Elderly relatives of mine live within such a zone and I often see cars seeming to roar past but in fact they might only be doing  or  mph. It is still too fast and so the limit needs greater enforcement.• A mph limit in rural roads. The current speed limit on single carriageway roads, denoted by the national speed limit sign in the picture on this page, is mph. Also, far greater construction of overtaking lanes on major single carriageways so that motorists do not get struck behind tractors and tempted to overtake against oncoming traffic• A mph limit on dual carriageways that have deadly gap junctions in the central reservation, enforced by average speed cameras. The current A road in Co Down would have such a  limit until it is upgraded and the gap junctions removed .• A mph limt on dual carriageways that have flyover junctions . This would be enforced by average speed cameras.• An mph limit on motorways. This would be to let motorists know that it is not all puritanism, and that drivers would be allowed to go a good pace on our safest roads. It too would be enforced by average speed cameras so that  means , not . It would further be enforced by cameras to ensure motorists keep their distance between vehicles in front, and do not sit in the overtaking lane.• No new planning permission whatsoever granted for entries directly on A roads. And any existing entrances on to A roads that can be moved to adjoining lanes would be transferred to the quieter, safer road.Under my plan there would, in summary, be a lot more average speed cameras, which would become cheaper with technology advancements. Average speed cameras remove even the temptation to speed, because they cannot be evaded by suddenly slowing down for a fixed site camera, then speeding up again. But under the plan there would also be many more roads with mph limits , and some roads with higher limits still — the motorways. title: view senedd vaughan gething
story: It is an issue that features heavily in my assembly postbag.I have been contacted by a number of local residents who are concerned about the availability of GP or other health care professionals for an appointment.The recent National Survey results showed continued concern over access with  per cent of participants finding it dficult to make an appointment at their practice.However  per cent of us were happy with our last episode of local healthcare.The NHS is facing unprecedented challenges with rising demand, expectation and long term public health challenges.We face those challenges against a backdrop of austerity imposed by the UK Government.I have previously spoken about our investment in community pharmacy, mental health counselling and physiotherapy services as key parts of local healthcare.We are though all aware of the pressures on our hardworking GPs and their practice teams to meet demand.I am incredibly proud of all our NHS staff who do a fantastic job despite the challenges they face.There is no single solution to improving access and a number of initiatives are underway including poundm invested in this yearrsquos contract with GPs.I am confident that we will help to relieve pressure on our GPs whilst also meeting the publicrsquos expectation.Last week, I was delighted to announce that the Train Work Live scheme has once again helped to exceed our targets for GP training.I launched the scheme in  to promote Wales as an excellent place for doctors and their families to train, work and live.We know that there are very real challenges across about recruiting and retaining GPs. This is not unique to Wales but an issue across the UK.Itrsquos important we act to ensure that our health service is sustainable in the long term.Recent figures show excellent progress has been made again this year.I increased the number of GP training places from  to  this year.However we actually filled  places.This is an increase of  per cent on last year and is great news for us locally.In order to ensure that we can recruit the medical workforce our health service needs now and in the future we also need to look outside Wales. That is why I recently visited India.The British Association of Physicians of Indian Origin have led the Medical Training Initiativescheme to bring medical professionals from India to work in NHS Wales for up to two years.This partnership with NHS Wales has led to over  doctors a year for the last three years being offered positions in NHS Wales through the scheme.During my visit I had the pleasure of meeting with some of the candidates who have applied to train work and live in Wales for two years together with the NHS Wales recruitment team.Our message that Wales is an excellent place to Train, Work and Live is clearly having an effect at home and abroad.As ever, I would be interested on hearing your views on this, please do get in touch. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE Vale Foodbank is calling for candidates on all sides to pledge to protect people from hunger.The call comes after it was revealed , emergency food parcels were given to people in the Vale between April  and September  this year.Of this number,  went to children.The figures are a  per cent increase on the same period last year.The Vale Foodbank is part of the Trussell Trustrsquos network, which announced that the need for emergency food parcels in the UK is at an all-time high.The new figures come after the Trussell Trust released State of Hunger, the most in-depth study ever published into hunger and the drivers of food bank use in the UK.The findings revealed the average weekly income of people at food banks is only pound after paying housing costs, and almost one in five have no money coming in at all in the month before being referred for emergency food.The Vale Foodbank is backing the Trussell Trustrsquos call for candidates on all sides to work towards a future where no one needs a food bank and pledge to protect people from hunger by ensuring everyone has enough money for the basics.The Trussell Trust is asking our next government to end the five week wait for universal credit ensure benefit payments cover the cost of living and invest in local emergency support for people in crisis.The local increase in need for the food bank is due to people struggling with the five-week wait for a first universal credit payment and people receiving payments that donrsquot cover the cost of essentials.Vale Foodbank trustee, Susan Lloyd-Selby said: ldquoItrsquos a real concern that in just six months wersquove provide , emergency supplies to local people.ldquoThese figures donrsquot take into account our busiest time of year - as the colder weather draws in, we often find even more people needing our help.ldquoWe believe that everyone should have enough money coming in to cover the basics. But right now, more and more people in the Vale are being forced to our food bankrsquos doors.ldquoThis isnrsquot right.ldquoWhile our help is needed, wersquore dedicated to ensuring that people in our community without enough money for food are able to access emergency support.ldquoOur vital work in the community has only been possible because of the incredible generosity shown by local people who have donated food, time and funds.ldquoThank you.The Vale Foodbank is particularly in need of UHT milk, fruit juice, tinned meat, and tinned vegetables.The charity has asked for festive donations to be donated in early December at the latest, to ensure volunteers have enough time to process and distribute these donations to people before Christmas. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: welsh trekkers raise   marie curie hospice
story: The team included Marie Curie nurses, volunteers, and family members of those cared for by the charity, with the proceeds going to people in need across the country - including Penarthrsquos own Marie Curie hospice.They tackled demanding daily hikes of up to eight hours and took on the valleys and paddy fields of northern Vietnam.Lisa Richards, a Marie Curie nurse from Rhuddlan, was part of the group and has raised more than pound, for the charityrsquos services across Wales.Ms Richards has been working for the charity for almost  years and lost six stone in preparation for the challenge.She said: ldquoI am always amazed by the fantastic fundraisers who work tirelessly giving their time and energy to raise money for the charity, so thatrsquos why this year I wanted to be a part of that process.ldquoI was supported every step of the way on the trek by a fantastic group of people who lted me up when I stumbled and made me feel like Irsquod known them forever and Irsquove really made friends for le.Mariclare Carey-Jones, a BBC journalist and broadcaster and ambassador for the charityrsquos Cardf and the Vale hospice, took part in the challenge.ldquoAs an ambassador for the Vale hospice I know how important fundraising is in order to ensure the organisation can continue providing vital care and support for people with terminal illnesses and their families, she said.ldquoKnowing I could give something back to this fantastic charity that has done so much for me and my family was my main motivation for signing up to the Vietnam trek, while the opportunity to experience a new country and undertake an amazing challenge was a real added bonus.Now the charity is calling on people to sign up for its next trek to Patagonia, which will see funds raised for the Marie Curie Nursing Service across Wales - including care in the home and the hospice.Last year, Marie Curie nurses cared for more than , patients and their families across Wales, at a cost of more than poundm a year.Hannah Leckie, community fundraiser for Cardf and the Vale, said: ldquoOur treks are always very popular, whether itrsquos with people looking to take on a new challenge in a beautul country with stunning landscapes, or those whose family has been cared for at the hospice and want to give something back.ldquoWe think Patagonia could be the best adventure yet.ldquoIt will be offering all those taking part the trip of a letime while raising money for such an important local cause.To find out more about the Patagonia trek and to register your place, visit: https:tinyurl qpxnlf article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: gin  celebrate first birthday launch penarth gin
story: Gin , of Victoria Road, plans to celebrate their its birthday with a party on November .Over the course of the year, the enterprising owners ndash Ashley Boucher and Jacques Aviles ndash have seen the bar go from strength to strength, getting involved in the manufacturing process and even being filmed by BBC Wales.Penarth Gin was described by manager Gareth Llywellyn as a premium, triple distilled Welsh dry gin, naturally prominent with notes of juniper, liquorice, cardamom citrus, orris root and paradise.Mr Boucher said: ldquoFrom humble beginnings we have had a successful year and we can only thank our customers and staff for ensuring such a prosperous start, turning our dreams into reality.ldquoAs soon as we opened we knew we would be interested in venturing into the spirit manufacturing market and have since produced our very own Penarth Gin.Mr Aviles said: ldquoWe were selected by the BBC to take part in a new docuseries highlighting successful Welsh businesses run by young entrepreneurs. It looks at the journey each business has been through to get to where they are now and what plans they have for the future.ldquoGin  was chosen for its unique style and that we set it up together, two cousins under the age of .ldquoFilming took place over four sessions in the last six months, with the final planned shoot for the first year anniversary party. Wersquore very excited.Mr Boucher and Mr Aviles, along with new business partner David Cole, now plan to expand across South Wales and the West Country.The programme will be aired sometime before Christmas with the exact date still to be set. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: charlotte churchs school wins approval vale council
story: Ms Church now has permission to to open the school in her home in Dinas Powys.The Vale councils planning committee agreed to approve a planning application for the school this week.Part of the singers Awen Project, Ms Church has spoken of her hopes the project will soon start up more independent schools.As the Penarth Times previously reported, the former child star, musician, presenter and campaigner says she will pay for the school herself in its first year.It will be non fee-paying and will educate  children aged between nine and .Ms Church has said that the school would be aimed at children struggling in mainstream education, and offer pupils more of a say in their curriculum.Vale councillors were told the singer had begun teaching in her home two months ago, and that the application was therefore retrospective.The councillors were further told that the school would only be held in the Ms Churchs home for one year and the singer has agreed to the condition to find a new home for it by July  - with five options already shortlisted.The Vale councils highways department did not have any objections to the school and councillors approved the application. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale council announce new victorian style lampposts replace old ones
story: This follows claims from a civic group that the original lampposts were structurally safe.As the Penarth Times previously reported, Victorian lampposts across Penarth were being replaced earlier this year with modern LED lighting, with the Vale council citing concerns the existing posts were structurally unsafe.The removal of the posts prompted a community backlash. More than , people signed a petition to save the Victorian lamp posts, fearing a ldquoloss of valuable historic character from the streetscape in Penarth.A Vale council spokesman said: "ldquoThe council has recently approved a more suitable replacement column for the old Victorian lampposts which will be painted black and feature embellishments to match the Victorian period style as well as having a swan neck arrangement that will accommodate a suspended LED lantern to meet its energy reduction strategy. It is intended to roll out this replacement column by replacing the previously installed steel columns along Cwrt y Vil Road before the end of this calendar year."Penarth Civic Society alleged the posts were safe in a letter sent last week to the Vale councilrsquos head of visible services and council leader Neil Moore.David Noble of the Penarth Civic Society said: ldquoWe would like to ask that the programme of removal and replacement of Victorian lampposts in Penarth is suspended with immediate effect.ldquoWe are completely in favour of the councilrsquos policy to replace old inefficient street lighting with modern more energy efficient LED lighting units. However, we are firmly of the opinion that not enough effort has gone into the decision.ldquoIt seems that the council is spending over pound, on replacing each lamppost. When two posts in Kymin Terrace and Beach Lane were converted, the contractor expressed concern that the spigot on the column was not strong enough to support the new unit. We believe this remains the sole justication for the claim the units are unsound.ldquoWe have been in contact with several street lighting contractors. They have all confirmed as long as the posts are structurally sound at their base there is no reason they cannot be upgraded.ldquoWe feel the decision to scrap the old columns was taken prematurely, without proper consideration and is motivated by a desire for expedience rather than sensibility and care.A Vale council spokesman said: ldquoThe council has a duty to ensure that the street lighting is in a safe condition and does not pose a hazard to the general public. As a result, a number of the older Victorian lampposts in Penarth were recently replaced because they were considered electrically and structurally unsafe with holes evident in some columns. Given the many safety concerns with these old columns it was not practical or cost-effective to attempt repairs and maintain appropriate level of public safety.ldquoThe council is confident the new replacement columns will address many of the concerns previously raised and enable the remaining unsafe Victorian cast iron columns throughout Penarth to be sympathetically replaced in , preserving the character and nature of the roads and streets which currently benefit from the visual appearance of the old Victorina cast iron columns.ldquoWhile the new replacement columns with embellishments and swan neck are more expensive than standard columns the cost will be offset by conversion to LED lanterns with signicant environment benefits as they produce less Co and will be more economical to operate over the letime of the new units. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: view senedd andrew rt davies
story: Trains are often cancelled or subject to severe delays, and when they arenrsquot passengers travel on rolling stock almost  years old.The Welsh Assembly have long promised an end to the ldquopacer trains that were introduced in the s as a stopgap - actually made of bus parts.When the new Transport for Wales franchise began last year, Welsh transport minister Ken Skates promised us ldquoquick wins. Sadly, these ldquowins have not been quick, yet to become a reality.Penarth commuters are still being shuttled into work each morning on overcrowded pacers, and this is simply not good enough. The new rolling stock we were promised seems many years away, when the reality is we need it now. Welsh Government need to pull their finger out and sort this out. Transport is their responsibility and they need to get a grip of the situation.The controversial Barry incinerator is a saga that seems to be rumbling on and on. I have long held deep concerns about the site, with the minister responsible for making the decision indicating almost two years ago she was ldquominded to insist an Environmental Impact Assessment be carried out.This week in the Assembly, I raised these concerns yet again, and the minister confirmed that an Environmental Statement has been submitted by the developer and is currently being reviewed.
